with the remittance of any tax imposed by this chapter on or before the
twentieth day of each month, stating as follows:
      “I declare, under penalty of perjury, that the above accounting of rooms
rented is accurate and the tax payment made herein is accurate to the best of
my knowledge according to my business records.
      Signed                         Dated                            
      Title                                                   ”
(Ord. O2023-07, 10-16-2023)
2-8-9: FAILURE TO PAY OCCUPATIONAL TAX:
All remittances of occupancy tax collected pursuant to this article shall be
due and received in the Office of the City Finance Officer no later than the
twentieth day following the month for which the occupancy tax remittances are
due. All amounts that are not remitted as set forth above will be charged a
late fee in the amount of ten percent of the total amount due.
Failure to remit such tax shall constitute a violation of this chapter which
may be punishable by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or
imprisonment of up to thirty (30) days. Any unpaid balance under this article
shall constitute lien upon the property owned by the business or user of space
being taxed and shall become a lien against and shall run with property taxes
and assessments.
The City shall have the ability to deny the issuance of permits or licenses or
any renewals thereof to any business or premises that fails to conform to
provisions of this article, including, but not limited to, building permits,
malt beverage licenses, wine licenses and liquor licenses.
Nothing with this provision shall be construed as limiting any other rights
which the City has or may pursue in seeking collection of monies not paid under
the terms of this chapter. In the event this tax becomes subject to supervision
by the State through the State's department of revenue, any rights which the
City has herein shall be deemed cumulative to any powers which inure to the
benefit of the State. (Ord. O2023-07, 10-16-2023)
2-8-10: PAYMENT OF FEES:
In the event legal action is required to collect any delinquent assessments, if
there is a tax that has not been paid in accordance with this chapter, the
hotel, motel or lodging establishment failing to pay will be responsible for
and pay all attorney's fees and costs incurred by the City in collecting the
unpaid tax. (Ord. O2023-07, 10-16-2023)
2-8-11: COSTS INCURRED BY THE CITY IN ADMINISTERING THE OCCUPATIONAL TAX:
All costs incurred by the City of the City Finance Officer pursuant to this
article shall be paid from occupancy taxes collected under this article.
Administrative costs are not to exceed two percent. (Ord. O2023-07, 10-16-2023)
2-8-12: BUSINESS IMPROVEMENT DISTRICT NUMBER 4 BOARD:
There is hereby continued, as has been previously established pursuant to SDCL
Chapter 9-55, a Business Improvement District Number 4 Board.
   A..   Composition.
      1.   The BID 4 Board shall consist of nine (9) members. The Mayor and a
council representative shall constitute two (2) members of the BID 4 board and
shall not be subject to term limits. In addition to the Mayor and council
representative, the BID 4 board shall also consist of seven (7) additional
members, appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council. Persons
who are eligible to fill the seven (7) additional member seats of the BID 4
Board must be property owners, residents, business operators, or users of space
within the business area to be improved, and will consist of:
         a.   Five (5) hoteliers from within BID 4; and
         b.   Two (2) other eligible persons who are not hoteliers.
   B.   Terms. All members of the Board shall be appointed to serve a three
(3)-year term. A member of the Board may serve consecutive terms if so
appointed by the Mayor and Council. The terms for the five (5) non-city members
shall initially be staggered so that three (3) member serves a full three (3)-
year term, two (2) members serve two (2)-year initial terms, and two (2)
members serve one (1)-year initial terms.
   C.   Vacancies. The Mayor, with the approval of the City Council, shall fill
any vacancy of members for the remainder of the term vacated.
   D.   Officers. The BID 4 Board shall annually select from its members a
chair, vice chair, and secretary.
   E.   Compensation. All members of the Board shall serve as such without
compensation, except for actual expenses, which shall be subject to approval of
the City Council.
   F.   Powers of the board. The primary duty of the BID 4 board is to
recommend a budget for the use of BID proceeds to the City Council. The use of
BID 4 proceeds is limited to the purposes provided under Section 2-8-4 above.
The BID 4 board shall be authorized to take such actions necessary to carry out
the appropriated expenditures included in the Council's approved budget for BID
4, upon any such further restrictions the Mayor and Council may provide during
the budget approval process. (Ord. O2023-07, 10-16-2023; amd. Ord. O2024-01, 2-
5-2024)
2-8-13: SEVERABILITY:
Should any section, clause or provision of this chapter be declared invalid,
the same shall not affect the validity of the ordinance as a whole or any part
thereof, other than the part declared to be invalid. (Ord. O2023-07, 10-16-
2023)
2-8-14: REPORTING:
The BID 4 Board will provide annual reports of their activities to the City
Council. (Ord. O2023-07, 10-16-2023)
2-8-15: DISSOLUTION OF THE DISTRICT:
BID 4 may be dissolved pursuant to SDCL 9-55-22, however there shall be no
requirement that the revenue collected from the tax be used only for the
promotion of the district in order for a majority of landowners to petition for
dissolution. (Ord. O2023-07, 10-16-2023)
TITLE 3
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
BOARD AND COMMISSION MEMBERS
SECTION:
3-1-1: Appointment Procedures
3-1-2: Powers And Duties
3-1-3: Advisory Boards
3-1-4: Rules
3-1-1: APPOINTMENT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Appointment: Unless otherwise provided by law or ordinance, members of
boards, commissions and standing committees of the city shall be residents of
the city or an owner of a business within the city of Mitchell, which owner has
a Mitchell, South Dakota, mailing address, or an owner of real property within
the city of Mitchell, which owner has a Mitchell, South Dakota, mailing
address, and appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. The
appointments shall generally be made and confirmed at the first regular city
council meeting in July of each year, or at any other meeting as shall be
deemed appropriate by the mayor and city council. Persons appointed as members
of a board, commission or committee of the city shall serve at the pleasure of
the mayor and city council. (Ord. 2470, 4-21-2014)
   B.   Terms: Unless otherwise provided by law or ordinance, the term of
appointment shall be for three (3) years. Terms of members shall be staggered,
such that to the extent possible, the terms of proportionately equal numbers of
members shall expire annually. No person shall serve more than two (2)
successive terms without at least one year intervening, unless the city council
shall waive such requirement. A person appointed to fill an unexpired term may
be appointed successively for two (2) complete full terms. (Ord. 2269, 2-18-
2008)
   C.   Unexpired Terms: Subject to the approval of the city council, the mayor
shall appoint persons to fill the unexpired term of any appointed person who
for any reason shall vacate an appointed position prior to the expiration of
the term.
   D.   Withdrawal Of Appointment: Whenever the mayor shall deem it in the best
interests of the city, the mayor shall have authority to withdraw any
previously made and approved appointment; and the appointment of any such
person shall be terminated upon such withdrawal of appointment by the mayor.
The mayor shall report any withdrawal of appointment to the city council at the
next regular city council meeting. (2005 Code)
3-1-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
Unless otherwise provided by law or ordinance, the powers and duties of the
boards, commissions and committees of the city shall be as from time to time
prescribed by the mayor and the city council; and all acts of the boards,
commissions or committees of the city shall be subject to the supervision and
review of the mayor and city council. Except where otherwise provided by law,
nothing contained in this title shall limit the superior authority of the city
council to effect any decision it shall enact in respect to the subject matter
of this title. Each board, commission or committee of the city may, subject to
the approval of the city council, enact rules for the orderly conduct of its
business. (2005 Code)
3-1-3: ADVISORY BOARDS:
The city council, by resolution, may establish an advisory board of citizens
for the purpose of providing advice and assistance to any department or
division within the city. Unless otherwise provided and authorized by law, an
advisory board so established shall have no official authority. (2005 Code)
3-1-4: RULES:
Each board, commission or committee established or appointed by the city shall
have power to establish such procedural rules as deemed necessary by it for the
orderly conduct of its business. (2005 Code)
CHAPTER 2
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
SECTION:
3-2-1: Commission Established
3-2-2: Powers And Duties
3-2-1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
   A.   The planning and zoning commission of the city shall consist of not
less than five (5) members appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city
council. The full term of each of the members shall be for five (5) years, and
shall be on a rotating basis so that the term of at least one member shall
expire each year. Appointment for partial terms may be made in order to
establish or maintain the membership rotation provided for herein.
   B.   The commission shall elect is chair from among its members for a term
of one year, with eligibility for reelection, and may fill such other of its
offices as it may create in the manner prescribed by the rules of the
commission. (Ord. 1812, 8-7-1995)
3-2-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The planning and zoning commission shall exercise and perform all powers and
duties as are, or may be, provided by law. (Ord. 1812, 8-7-1995)

3-3-3: Powers And Duties
3-3-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
A board of adjustment is hereby established which shall consist of all of the

3-3-2: ORGANIZATION:

in the keeping of the provisions of the zoning title 1 . Meetings shall be held
at the call of the chair and at such other times as the board may determine.
   B.   Meetings: The chair or, in his absence, the president of the city
council, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All
meetings shall be open to the public 2 .
   C.   Minutes And Records: The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings,
showing the vote of each member on each question or if absent or failing to
vote, indicate such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other
official actions and the reasons for such actions, all of which shall be a
public record and be immediately filed with the finance officer. (Ord. 1270, 5-
23-1977)

  10-3-3 of this code.
CHAPTER 4
HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
3-4-1: Purpose
3-4-2: Commission Established
3-4-3: Powers And Duties
3-4-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter and any subsequent enactments or amendments hereto
is to promote, preserve and develop the historical resources of the city in
accordance with the provisions of South Dakota Codified Laws chapter 1-19B.
(Ord. 1507, 8-5-1985)
3-4-2: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED:
The city council hereby authorizes the establishment of an historic
preservation commission, hereinafter referred to as the "commission", to
preserve, promote and develop the historical resources of the city in
accordance with the provisions of South Dakota Codified Laws chapter 1-19B.
   A.   Membership: The commission shall consist of not less than five (5) nor
more than ten (10) members who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by
the city council. Commission members shall be appointed with due regard to
proper representation of such fields as history, architecture, urban planning,
archeology and law.
   B.   Terms Of Office: All commission members shall reside within the city
and shall serve a term of three (3) years; except, that when the commission is
first appointed, the lengths of the terms shall be varied in such a fashion as
to assure that no more than one-third (1/3) of the terms expire in any given
year. Thereafter, appointment of each member shall be for a full three (3) year
term unless the appointment is made to fill a vacancy. Said members shall be
eligible for reappointment as specified by the city council.
   C.   Organization: The commission shall elect officers from its membership
to consist of a chair, vice chair and secretary who shall serve a term of one
year. The commission shall hold an annual organization meeting for the purpose
of electing officers.
   D.   Staff: The commission may employ such personnel as it deems necessary.
(Ord. 1507, 8-5-1985)
3-4-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The historic preservation commission established pursuant to section
3-4-2 of this chapter shall be authorized to:
   A.   General:
      1.   Conduct a survey of local historic properties, complying with all
applicable standards and criteria of the statewide survey undertaken by the
cultural preservation office of the department of education and cultural
affairs.
      2.   Acquire fee and lesser interest in historic properties, including
adjacent or associated lands by purchase, bequest or donation. All lands,
buildings or structures acquired by the commission with funds other than those
appropriated by the city may be acquired and held in the name of the
commission, the city, or both.
      3.   Preserve, restore, maintain and operate historic properties under
the ownership or control of the commission.
      4.   Lease, sell and otherwise transfer or dispose of historic properties
subject to rights of public access and other covenants and in a manner that
will preserve the property.
      5.   Contract, with the approval of the city council, with the state or
the federal government or any agency of either, or with any other organization.
      6.   Cooperate with the federal, state and local governments in the
pursuance of the objectives of historic preservation.
      7.   Participate in the conduct of land use, urban renewal and other
planning processes undertaken by the city.
      8.   Recommend ordinances and otherwise provide information to the city
council for the purposes of historic preservation.
      9.   Promote and conduct an educational, interpretative program on
historic properties within the city.
      10.   Enter, solely in the performance of its official duties and only at
reasonable times, upon private lands for examination or survey thereof.
However, no member, employee or agent of the commission may enter any private
building or structure without the express consent of the owner or occupant
thereof.
   B.   Notice To Director Of Equalization: Upon the adoption of this or any
subsequent amendments designating historic properties within the city, the
historic preservation commission shall give notice of such designation to the
director of equalization of Davison County. The designation and any recorded
restrictions upon the property limiting its use for preservation purposes shall
be considered by the director of equalization in appraising the property for
tax purposes. (Ord. 1507, 8-5-1985)

ARTS COUNCIL

TRAFFIC COMMISSION

CHAPTER 7
PARK AND RECREATION BOARD
SECTION:
3-7-1: Board Established
3-7-2: Board Membership
3-7-3: Powers And Duties
3-7-4: Use Of Water From City Mains
3-7-5: Special Fund
3-7-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created and established the park and recreation board of the
city, created according to law as a combined board, as provided by South Dakota
Codified Laws 9-38-90.1. The park and recreation board shall consist of seven
(7) members, and shall exercise of all of the powers and duties that the park
board and recreation board are, and have been, permitted to exercise separately
by law 1 . (1984 Code § 26-14; amd. 2005 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. SDCL § 9-38-90 et seq.
3-7-2: BOARD MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   Appointment: The park and recreation board shall be under the control
and supervision of the city council and the city council shall prescribe all
rules, regulations and responsibilities of the said park and recreation board
in a manner not inconsistent with law. (1984 Code § 26-15; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Oath And Bond: Before entering upon his official duties, each member of
the park and recreation board shall file with the finance officer the usual
oath of office and, if required by the city council, bond for the faithful
performance of his duties. (1984 Code § 26-17; amd. 2005 Code)
   C.   Qualification Of Appointees: Any resident of the city of Mitchell, an
owner of a business within the city of Mitchell, any property owner of property
within the city of Mitchell, and any person who works in the city of Mitchell,
with a Mitchell, South Dakota address, may be appointed as a member of the park
and recreation board by the mayor, and confirmed by the city council. (Ord.
2304, 5-4-2009)
3-7-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The park and recreation board shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   Parkways And Parkings:
      1.   To manage, supervise and maintain the parks and parkways, except
parkings of the city, as provided by statute 1  and applicable ordinance.
      2.   To manage and supervise the parkings in the city as provided by
statute and applicable ordinance.
   B.   Landscaping:
      1.   To control and manage the planting, maintenance, trimming and
removal of trees, shrubs and plants in any and all public grounds,
thoroughfares and lands appurtenant thereto, throughout the city. (1984 Code §
26-18)
      2.   To have exclusive power and control over all trees, shrubs, plants
and grass planted in parks and parkways, including planting, pruning, spraying,
cultivating, preserving and otherwise maintaining the same.
      3.   No person shall plant, remove, prune or spray any tree, shrub or
plant in any park or parkway, without the written permission of the park and
recreation board, or its authorized representative.
      4.   No person shall hinder, obstruct or interfere with any employee or
agent of the park and recreation board, while engaged in carrying out the
provisions of this chapter. (1984 Code § 26-20)
   C.   Public Recreation System:
      1.   To create, manage, supervise, maintain and operate the system of
public recreation.
      2.   To manage, create, supervise and operate playgrounds and children's
parks.
      3.   To acquire, equip and maintain land, buildings or other recreational
facilities and expend its funds therefor.
      4.   To determine and set user fees for all programs, services and for
the use of public recreational facilities as deemed appropriate by the board.
(1984 Code § 26-18)
   D.   Rules And Regulations: To make rules and regulations governing the
conduct of all persons within any public park, parkways, parkings, public
grounds or any of the recreation system, lands, buildings or other facilities
controlled by the park and recreation board. Such rules and regulations shall
be effective upon being posted in a conspicuous place within or upon such
lands, buildings or other recreational facilities. No person shall violate any
such rule conspicuously posted in or upon any land, buildings or recreational
facilities. (1984 Code § 26-21)
   E.   Acceptance Of Gifts: It may accept gifts or bequests for the benefit of
such park and recreational service. (1984 Code § 26-22)
   F.   Additional Powers And Duties: To have such other powers and duties as
provided by statute and applicable ordinances. (1984 Code § 26-18)
 
Notes
1 1. SDCL §§ 9-38-91, 9-38-92.
3-7-4: USE OF WATER FROM CITY MAINS:
The park and recreation board, in its use of water from the city mains, shall
comply with the rules and regulations of the water department as to the amount
of water used and the time of such usage. (1984 Code § 26-19)
3-7-5: SPECIAL FUND:
The receipts derived from any separate levies provided for park and recreation
purposes shall be maintained in a single account, in accordance with South
Dakota Codified Laws 9-38-90.3, and the same shall be used, disbursed and spent
for the purposes determined by the board, and said board shall be responsible
for any funds in said account and shall be responsible to the city council for
its administration of said account. (1984 Code § 26-16)
CHAPTER 8
AIRPORT ADVISORY COMMITTEE
(Repealed By Ord. O2019-16, 8-19-2019)
CHAPTER 9
CORN PALACE ENTERTAINMENT BOARD
SECTION:
3-9-1: Board Established
3-9-2: Board Membership And Terms
3-9-3: Appointment
3-9-4: Organization Of Board
3-9-5: Corn Palace Festival
3-9-6: Murals And Decorations
3-9-7: Contracts
3-9-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
For the purpose of administering, conducting and promoting entertainment
activities for the Corn Palace, including, but not limited to, the annual Corn
Palace Festival, there is established the Corn Palace entertainment board as
provided in the following sections of this chapter. The board shall hold such
meetings as it shall deem necessary to manage, conduct, and carry out its
duties. (Ord. 2487, 10-20-2014; amd. Ord. 2556, 12-5-2016; Ord. O2019-22, 10-7-
2019)
3-9-2: BOARD MEMBERSHIP AND TERMS:
   A.   The Corn Palace entertainment board shall consist of nine (9) members
as further provided by this section.
   B.   The mayor shall appoint, subject to city council approval, one (1)
member of the Mitchell city council to serve for such time as designated by the
mayor.
   C.   The mayor shall appoint, subject to city council approval, seven (7)
citizens of the city who shall serve up to two (2) consecutive terms of three
(3) years each. The terms of the citizen members of the board shall be
staggered such that an approximately equal number of citizen member terms shall
expire each year.
   D.   The mayor shall appoint, subject to city council approval, one (1)
member nominated by the Mitchell chamber of commerce executive board who shall
then be serving on said executive board. This member may serve indefinitely
unless said member no longer meets the eligibility criteria for this position
or is removed by the mayor.
   E.   The mayor may remove any member from their position on the Corn Palace
entertainment board at any time.
   F.   Each member of the board, following expiration of an appointed term,
shall serve until a successor is appointed and qualified, unless that member is
disqualified for reason other than term expiration. (Ord. 2487, 10-20-2014;
amd. Ord. 2556, 12-5-2016; Ord. O2019-22, 10-7-2019)
3-9-3: APPOINTMENT:
   A.   The members of the board composed as in the preceding section of this
chapter provided who are subject to appointment in any given year, shall be
appointed by the mayor at the first regular city council meeting in October of
each year, or at such other time as shall be convenient for the mayor and the
city council. Vacancies in any board position shall be filled at any time by
nomination by the mayor and approval by the city council. A person appointed to
fill a vacancy on the board occurring for reason other than expiration of
eligibility of any member shall be eligible for reappointment to the board for
the full term of eligibility which would exist without consideration of the
completion of a partial term filled upon a vacancy occurring for reasons other
than expiration of a prior member's term. All members of the board, regardless
of the method by which such membership was obtained, shall be entitled to vote
on all matters which come before the board in respect to the business of the
board.
   B.   In the event that the mayor is for any reason unable to find a willing
and qualified nominee acceptable to the mayor, the city council, may by
majority vote, waive the limitation on successive terms in respect to any board
member. (Ord. 2487, 10-20-2014; amd. Ord. O2019-22, 10-7-2019)
3-9-4: ORGANIZATION OF BOARD:
The Corn Palace entertainment board shall organize by annually electing
officers from its membership consisting of a president and vice president.
There shall be no limit on successive terms in respect to any officer of the
board. The sole qualification for holding an office within the board shall be
board membership. (Ord. 2487, 10-20-2014; amd. Ord. O2019-22, 10-7-2019)
3-9-5: CORN PALACE FESTIVAL:
The board shall, under the supervision of the mayor and city council, have full
charge of the arrangements for and the management and conduct of the Corn
Palace Festival and associated entertainment; and may, subject to the
supervision of the mayor and city council, conduct promotional activities
relating to the annual Corn Palace Festival and associated entertainment and
other appropriate purposes. (Ord. 2487, 10-20-2014)
3-9-6: MURALS AND DECORATIONS:
The Corn Palace entertainment board shall, under the supervision of the mayor
and city council, select and develop an annual theme for the exterior, and when
appropriate, the interior, of the Corn Palace. The theme selected by the board
shall provide direction to the artist employed by the board for the annual
redecoration of the exterior murals of the Corn Palace, and when appropriate
and directed by the mayor and city council, the murals within the interior of
the Corn Palace. All decorations upon the Corn Palace, whether interior or
exterior, shall be subject to supervision and final approval of the mayor and
city council. (Ord. 2487, 10-20-2014)
3-9-7: CONTRACTS:
The Corn Palace entertainment board shall have power to execute and carry out
contracts in furtherance of its authorized purposes. (Ord. 2487, 10-20-2014)

MUSEUM BOARD
(Repealed By Ord. O2019-17, 8-19-2019)
CHAPTER 11
COMMUNITY SERVICES ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
3-11-1: Board Established
3-11-2: Board Membership And Terms
3-11-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
For the purposes of recommending and advising the community services director
on departmental functions, there is established the community services advisory
board which shall consist of nine (9) members, the makeup and appointment of
which are as further provided in this chapter. (Ord. 2546, 7-18-2016)
3-11-2: BOARD MEMBERSHIP AND TERMS:
The community services advisory board shall consist of one member of the
Mitchell city council, two (2) members from the Palace Transit division, two
(2) members from the RSVP division, two (2) members from the nutrition
division, and two (2) members from the James Valley Community Center
membership. Each member of the board shall be appointed in accordance with
section
3-1-1 of this title. (Ord. 2546, 7-18-2016)
CHAPTER 12
GOLF AND CEMETERY BOARD
SECTION:
3-12-1: Board Established
3-12-2: Board Membership
3-12-3: Powers And Duties
3-12-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created and established the golf and cemetery board of the
city. The golf and cemetery board shall be under the control and supervision of
the city council and the city council shall prescribe all rules, regulations,
and responsibilities of the said golf and cemetery board in a manner not
inconsistent with law. The golf and cemetery board shall consist of seven (7)
members, and shall exercise all of the powers and duties that the golf and
cemetery board have been granted under this chapter. (Ord. O2020-16, 12-21-
2020)
3-12-2: BOARD MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   Oath And Bond: Before entering upon his official duties, each member of
the golf and cemetery board shall file with the finance officer the usual oath
of office and, if required by the city council, bond for the faithful
performance of the member's duties.
   B.   Qualification Of Appointees: Any resident of the city of Mitchell, an
owner of a business within the city of Mitchell, any property owner of property
within the city of Mitchell, and any person who works in the city of Mitchell,
with a Mitchell, South Dakota address, may be appointed as a member of the golf
and cemetery board by the mayor, and confirmed by the city council at the first
regular city council meeting in October of each year, or at such other time as
shall be convenient for the mayor and the city council.
   C.   Term:
      1.   Each board member shall serve for a term of three (3) years. The
terms of the board members shall be staggered such that an approximately equal
number of member terms shall expire each year. Eligibility for golf and
cemetery board member positions shall not be limited by serving any number of
consecutive terms.
      2.   At the time this chapter is adopted, all current members serving on
the golf and cemetery board are reappointed to serve the remainder of their
respective terms.
      3.   The mayor shall have the authority to remove a member of the golf
and cemetery board at any time.
   D.   Organization: The golf and cemetery board shall elect is chair from
among its members for a term of one year, with eligibility for reelection, and
may fill such other of its offices as it may create in the manner prescribed by
the rules of the commission. (Ord. O2020-16, 12-21-2020)
3-12-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The golf and cemetery board shall have the purpose of managing, overseeing,
supervising, and guiding the operations of the Lakeview Golf Course and
Mitchell Cemetery in connection with the department head and staff responsible
for these locations. The golf and cemetery board shall have the following
powers and duties:
   A.   General Powers:
      1.   To set such rules and procedures as may be necessary for the conduct
of its meetings.
      2.   To determine and set user fees for all programs, services, and for
the use of golf and cemetery facilities as deemed appropriate by the board. The
golf and cemetery board shall provide notice to the City Council of any changes
to the board's fees and the City Council reserves the power to adjust such
fees.
      3.   To execute and carry out contracts in furtherance of its authorized
purposes.
      4.   To make rules and regulations governing the conduct of all persons
within the Lakeview Golf Course and Mitchell Cemetery grounds and facilities.
Such rules and regulations shall be effective upon being posted in a
conspicuous place within or upon such grounds and facilities. No person shall
violate any such rule conspicuously posted in or upon any such grounds and
facilities.
   B.   Acceptance Of Gifts: The golf and cemetery board may accept gifts or
bequests for the benefit of its facilities.
   C.   Additional Powers And Duties: To have such other powers and duties as
provided by statute and applicable ordinances. (Ord. O2020-16, 12-21-2020)
TITLE 4
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
4-1-1: Business Licenses Or Permits Required
4-1-2: Application For License Or Permit
4-1-3: Issuance; Conditions Of License Or Permit
4-1-4: Exemptions
4-1-5: Revocation Of License Or Permit
4-1-6: Appeal Procedures
4-1-1: BUSINESS LICENSES OR PERMITS REQUIRED:
If a license or permit is required for certain business or activities by any
provision of this code, then no person shall engage in those businesses or
activities without first having obtained such license or permit as required by
this code. This chapter does not apply to zoning matters or matters governed by
the uniform codes administered by the city’s public works department, police
department, or fire and EMS department. (Ord. 2444, 7-15-2013; amd. Ord. O2020-
14, 12-7-2020)
4-1-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE OR PERMIT:
Except as otherwise provided, an applicant for license or permit required by
the provisions of this code shall make and file an application, in writing,
with the finance officer on the form from time to time prescribed by the city
finance officer.
   A.   Unless otherwise provided, an application for license or permit shall
state:
      1.   Name and address of applicant.
      2.   Trade name, if any, under which license or permit is to be
exercised.
      3.   If a partnership, the name and address of each partner.
      4.   If a corporation or LLC, the names and addresses of the principal
officer(s) or manager(s).
      5.   Place of business or location where the license or permit is to be
exercised.
      6.   Description of the activity to be carried on under the license or
permit.
      7.   Such information as required by this code or other ordinance or by
the city council showing the applicant to be entitled to the license or permit
and that he/she is a proper person and the place a proper place for exercise
thereof.
      8.   Such information as required by this code or other ordinance as may
be necessary for determination of the amount of the license or permit fee.
   B.   Except as otherwise provided, an applicant for license or permit shall
first pay the amount of the license or permit fee to the finance officer,
taking his/her receipt therefor, showing the kind of license or permit for
which the fee was paid and the amount paid. Such receipt shall be presented to
the licensing or permitting officer if other than the finance officer to whom
application for the license or permit is made. (Ord. 2444, 7-15-2013)
4-1-3: ISSUANCE; CONDITIONS OF LICENSE OR PERMIT:
   A.   Issuance By Finance Officer: Except as otherwise provided, all licenses
and permits shall be issued by the finance officer. If the issuance of the
license or permit is approved by a licensing and permitting authority other
than the finance officer the applicant shall provide proof of compliance with
all requirements for issuance of the license or permit, including conforming to
the zoning regulations of the city, to the issuing authority. If the use for
which a license or permit is applied for is a nonconforming use under the
zoning regulations, no license or permit shall be issued. Unless otherwise
provided, all licenses and permits shall be signed by the finance officer or
deputy finance officer and shall have affixed thereto the official seal of the
city.
   B.   Approval Of License Or Permit By The City Council: If the license or
permit is subject to approval by the city council the approval or disapproval
shall be entitled in the official minutes of the city council. No document
constituting the license or permit shall be issued.
   C.   Bond, Insurance Or Deposit: Any bond, liability insurance or deposit
required shall be subject to the approval of the city council, and in case the
city council deems the security inadequate, it may require new or additional
security.
   D.   Term Of License Or Permit: Unless otherwise provided, all licenses and
permits shall take effect when issued and shall terminate on December 31 in the
year for which issued. Except as otherwise provided, the fee charged for the
license or permit shall be paid on the basis of a full year.
   E.   License Or Permit To Be Exhibited: Every person to whom a license or
permit is issued by the city shall exhibit the license or permit if requested
by a law enforcement officer or any person who may deal with the license or
permit when reasonably requested to do so.
   F.   Change Of Business Name: If a licensee or permittee changes the name or
form of organization under which he/she does business, the license or permit
may be so changed without payment of an additional fee, except as otherwise
provided by law. (Ord. 2444, 7-15-2013)
4-1-4: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter as to licensing and permitting certain
activities shall not apply to those conducted as a part of the established Corn
Palace Week Festival. (Ord. 2444, 7-15-2013)
4-1-5: REVOCATION OF LICENSE OR PERMIT:
The city council shall have power to cancel and withdraw any license or permit
issued by the city for failure of the licensee or permittee to comply with any
ordinance or regulation of the city or state law respecting such license or
permit or the manner of exercise thereof or for other good cause after hearing
upon notice to the licensee or permittee.
Upon conviction of a violation of any provision of this code or other ordinance
of the city by a licensee or permittee relating to the exercise of such license
or permit, the court, in addition to other penalties imposed, may enter its
judgment canceling such license or permit. (Ord. 2444, 7-15-2013)
4-1-6: APPEAL PROCEDURES:
Any applicant aggrieved by the refusal of a city official to issue a license or
permit or by the revocation of a license or permit shall have the right to
appeal the official's decision to the city council. Such appeal shall be
requested by submitting a written request to the city finance officer within
five (5) days of the action from which the appeal is taken. The city council
shall consider the appeal at its next regularly scheduled meeting occurring at
least five (5) days following, at which time the applicant shall be entitled to
present his/her appeal orally or in writing. (Ord. 2444, 7-15-2013)

LIQUOR CONTROL

4-2-1: NUMBER OF ON-SALE MALT BEVERAGE LICENSES:

4-2-2: ON-SALE BEER AND OFF-SALE LIQUOR LICENSES:
(Rep. by Ord. O2018-04, 4-9-2018)
4-2-3: HOURS OF OPERATION:
   A.   Securing Of Alcoholic Beverages During Nonlegal Operating Hours:
      1.   Definitions: As used in this subsection the following terms shall
have the following meanings:
    LICENSEE: The holder of any license within the City for the on-sale or off-
sale of any alcoholic beverage, including malt beverages.
   NONLEGAL OPERATING HOURS: The hours of each day and the holidays or other
days during which a licensee is prohibited by State law from selling alcoholic
beverages 1 .
   PREMISES: The location defined under a licensee's license.
      2.   Security Required: Every licensee shall secure all alcoholic
beverages located, stored, or displayed on the licensee's premises during all
nonlegal operating hours. For premises which remain open to the public during
nonlegal operating hours, secure shall mean to place in a separate container or
room or a separately sealed or divided portion of a container or room in such a
manner that unauthorized persons cannot gain access. For premises that are
closed to the public during nonlegal operating hours, secure shall mean to
ensure that all non-staff persons have vacated the premises and lock all
entrance and exit points in a manner which prohibits non-staff persons from
entering the premises. (Ord. O2018-04, 4-9-2018)
 
Notes
1 1. SDCL § 35-4-81.
4-2-4: OPEN CONTAINERS:
   A.   Generally:
      1.   Unless explicitly exempt from this section, no alcoholic beverage
shall be sold, served for consumption, consumed, or possessed unless the seal
of the original package remains unbroken upon:
         a.   Any public street, highway, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, or other
location within public right of way; or
         b.   Any parking lot to which the public has access or which is open
or available to the public within the city; or
         c.   Any other place, whether in or out of a building, commonly and
customarily open to or used by the general public.
      2.   Consumption of alcoholic beverages in the following areas shall be
exempt from the restrictions of Section 4-2-4(A):
         a.   The area covered by a valid on-sale alcoholic beverage license,
including special event on-sale alcoholic beverage licenses.
         b.   The area approved by the city council pursuant to an application
for a consumption permit and, in such an event, the city council will approve
the container that will be exempt for the purposes of the consumption permit.
         c.   The immediate area where alcoholic beverage product sampling is
lawfully conducted pursuant to state law.
         d.   A city owned facility pursuant to a valid rental agreement
allowing the consumption of alcoholic beverages.
         e.   Upon the waters or ice of Lake Mitchell.
         f.   At any city park land abutting the shoreline of Lake Mitchell.
         g.   At the Soccer Complex, Mitchell Activities Center, and Cadwell
Sports Complex, and the parking lots adjacent thereto. However, the Park and
Recreation Board may adopt additional rules for these locations for the purpose
of preventing the consumption of alcoholic beverages at or in connection with
organized youth sporting activities. A violation of such Park and Recreation
Board rule shall be deemed a violation of this section.
         h.   At any other city park land authorized for consumption by the
Park and Recreation Board.
         i.   At the Lakeview Golf Course. However, the Golf and Cemetery Board
may adopt additional rules for the purpose of preventing the consumption of
alcoholic beverages at or in connection with organized youth sporting
activities. A violation of such Golf and Cemetery Board rule shall be deemed a
violation of this section.
      3.   No person shall use a glass alcoholic beverage container while
consuming an alcoholic beverage at any location identified in Section 4-2-4(A)
(1). However, the area covered by a valid on-sale alcoholic beverage license,
including special event on-sale alcoholic beverage licenses, shall be exempt
from this prohibition on the use of glass containers.
   B.    Liquor Establishments: No licensee holding any alcoholic beverage
license of whatever nature shall permit any person to leave the premises for
which said license is issued with any container on which the tap or seal has
been broken and which contains any amount of an alcoholic beverage, except as
authorized by the city council via consumption permit pursuant to South Dakota
Codified Laws 35-1-5.3 and in connection with special events the city council
will approve the container that will be used for the special event.
   C.   Licensee Sealed Alcoholic Beverages: An alcoholic beverage licensee may
allow a person to leave the licensed premises with an alcoholic beverage that
is not factory sealed so long as the licensee complies with the provisions of
this section and does not otherwise violate state law. A licensee may allow a
person to leave the licensed premises with an alcoholic beverage for the
purposes of bulk sales, off-premises consumption of a partially consumed
alcoholic beverage purchased with a meal, or sale of an alcoholic beverage in
conjunction with a to-go food order. If allowing a person to leave the licensed
premises with an alcoholic beverage, the licensee shall seal the alcoholic
beverage container in a manner which identifies the licensed premises sealing
the beverage and provides clear visual evidence that the alcoholic beverage
container has been unsealed. The seal shall also prevent any of the contents of
the alcoholic beverage container from being consumed without breaking the seal.
(Ord. 2360, 4-18-2011; amd. Ord. O2022-11, 7-5-2022)
4-2-5: MINORS 1 :
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have
the following meanings:
    LICENSEE: The holder of any license within the City of Mitchell for the
sale, whether on-sale, off-sale or both, of any alcoholic beverage, including
malt beverages.
   TAVERN OR BAR: Any place of business licensed for the sale of any alcoholic
beverages, including malt beverages, which actually derives more than fifty
percent (50%) of its gross proceeds from the sale of alcoholic beverages.
   UNDERAGE PERSON (MINOR): Any person who is below the age determined by State
law for lawful purchase of the alcoholic beverages sold by a licensee at a
particular tavern or bar 2 .
   B.   Underage Persons Prohibited; Exception:
      1.   No licensee who operates a tavern or bar shall suffer or permit any
underage person to enter or remain on the premises of such tavern or bar,
except in the immediate presence of the underage person's parent, legal
guardian or spouse, if the spouse is not an underage person.
      2.   No underage person may enter, attempt to enter or remain on the
premises of a tavern or bar.
      3.   A licensee who operates a tavern or bar may employ an underage
person if such employment complies with South Dakota Codified Law 35-4-79.4.
Such underage person may only be present on the licensee’s premises for work
purposes.
   C.   Signs Posted: Any licensee who operates a tavern or bar shall
conspicuously post a sign in a place and in a manner so as to be readily
visible to and easily read by any person entering the tavern or bar stating
that no persons under the lawful age for that tavern or bar may enter and
stating the applicable age under the provisions of this section and applicable
State law 3 . (Ord. 1551, 6-1-1987; amd. Ord. O2022-11, 7-5-2022)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 6, chapter 4 of this Code.
2 2. SDCL § 35-4-79.
3 2.    SDCL § 35-4-79.
4-2-6: VIDEO LOTTERY MACHINES:
Every person, including corporations or other organizations, within the City,
who is licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages, on-sale, pursuant to South
Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-2 (4), (6), (11), (13) or (16), and who is issued a
video lottery establishment license pursuant to South Dakota Codified Laws 42-
7A-41, shall pay to the City for the privilege of locating video lottery
machines on the licensed premises, an annual additional license fee (in
addition to the fees imposed under South Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-2 and 42-7A-
41) as established from time to time by resolution of the City Council for each
video lottery machine placed or to be placed in or upon the licensed premises
at any time during the term of the license. The total additional license fee
paid shall represent the maximum number of video lottery machines which may be
placed in or upon the licensed premises at any one time during the term of the
license. Such fees shall be payable to the Finance Office at the same time and
in the same manner as license fees paid pursuant to South Dakota Codified Laws
35-4-2, provided that the fees provided for in this section shall not be
imposed on more than one license per location. (Ord. 1729, 11-16-1992)
   A.   Wine licenses issued with video lottery are limited to those licenses
that were issued as of April 1, 2007, or were applied for on or before April 1,
2007; otherwise no wine licenses will be issued with video lottery. Any
previously issued wine license that did not request its issuance with video
lottery will not be authorized to request video lottery with said license.
(Ord. 2239, 6-4-2007)
   B.   On-off sale malt beverage (RB) licenses issued with video lottery are
limited to those licenses that were issued as of April 1, 2018, or were applied
for on or before April 1, 2018; otherwise no on-off sale malt beverage (RB)
licenses will be issued with video lottery. Any previously issued on-off sale
malt beverage (RB) license that did not request its issuance with video lottery
will not be authorized to request video lottery with said license. (Ord. O2018-
04, 4-9-2018)
4-2-7: MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUMS, PUBLIC CONVENTION HALLS, AND SPECIAL EVENT
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE LICENSES:
   A.   Municipal Auditorium And Public Convention Hall On-Sale Licenses: Any
Municipal auditorium or public convention hall, through its director or
operator, may apply for an on-sale liquor license pursuant to South Dakota
Codified Laws 35-4-14.1 and, if granted, may use and renew the on-sale liquor
license as provided by law.
   B.   Special Event Alcoholic Beverage Licenses: Special event alcoholic
beverage licenses, under South Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-124, may be issued by
the City Council in conjunction with special events held within the City of
Mitchell. Any license issued pursuant to this section may be issued for a
period of time established by the City Council, not to exceed fifteen (15)
consecutive days. The license shall be applied for and issued in the same
manner as other alcohol licenses issued by the City of Mitchell, except as
further provided in this section.
      1.   Special Application Requirements: Any application for a special
event alcoholic beverage license shall include the class of special alcoholic
beverage license applied for and contain a map of the intended location for use
of the special event alcoholic beverage license.
      2.   Effect Of Boundaries For Licenses: The sale of alcoholic beverages
pursuant to a special event alcoholic beverage license shall not take place
beyond the boundaries shown on the map. Alcoholic beverages sold pursuant to an
off-sale special event alcoholic beverage license shall not be consumed at the
location of the sale. Consumption of alcoholic beverages sold pursuant to an
on-sale special event alcoholic beverage license may occur within the same
boundaries set for the sale of alcoholic beverages and may only occur outside
of those boundaries in conjunction with a consumption permit issued by the City
Council pursuant to subsection
4-2-4B1 of this chapter and South Dakota Codified Laws 35-1-5.5.
      3.   Hours Of Effect: The City Council, when granting a special event
alcoholic beverage license, shall set the hours for which the special event
alcoholic beverage license shall be effective with such hours never to exceed
those for an on-sale alcoholic beverage dealer.
      4.   Fees Set By City Council: The fees for each special event alcoholic
beverage license shall be set by the City Council by resolution.
      5.   Hearing Requirement: A public hearing shall be required for special
event alcoholic beverage licenses in the same manner as for other alcohol
licenses. However, no public hearing shall be required for an event held on
publicly owned property by an applicant for a special event alcoholic beverage
license who already holds the corresponding class of permanent alcohol license
issued by the City of Mitchell.
      6.   Limits On Issuance: No person may be issued more than two hundred
(200) special event alcoholic beverage licenses within any calendar year. For
calculation purposes, any combination of licenses issued to the same person, at
the same place, for the same time, and for the same special event, shall be
counted only as one license for purposes of the two hundred (200) license
limit.
   C.   Types Of Special Event Alcoholic Beverage Licenses And Classes Of
Eligibility: The following types of special event alcoholic beverage licenses
are available to the corresponding classes of applicants for use in conjunction
with a special event in the City of Mitchell:
      1.   Special Malt Beverage Retailer's License: Available to any civic,
charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans' organization or any licensee
licensed pursuant to South Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-2(4), (6), or (16). (Ord.
2533, 4-4-2016)
      2.   Special On-Sale Wine Retailer's License: Available to any civic,
charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans' organization or any licensee
licensed pursuant to South Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-2(4), (6), or (12) or any
farm winery license. (Ord. O2018-04, 4-9-2018)
      3.   Special On-Sale License: Available to any civic, charitable,
educational, fraternal, or veterans' organization or any licensee licensed
pursuant to South Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-2(4) or (6).
      4.   Special Off-Sale Package Wine Dealer's License: Special off- sale
package wine dealer's licenses are available in the following situations: (Ord.
2533, 4-4-2016)
         a.   Any civic, charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans'
organization or any licensee licensed pursuant to South Dakota Codified Laws
35-4-2(3), (5), or (12), or any farm winery license. A special off-sale package
wine dealer's licensee may only sell wine manufactured by a farm winery
license; or (Ord. O2018-04, 4-9-2018)
         b.   Any civic, charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans'
organization in conjunction with a special event conducted pursuant to
subsection C7 of this section.
      5.   Special Off-Sale Package Malt Beverage Dealer's License: Available
to any civic, charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans' organization in
conjunction with a special event, conducted pursuant to subsection C7 of this
section.
      6.   Special Off-Sale Package Dealer's License: Available to any civic,
charitable, educational, fraternal, or veterans' organization in conjunction
with a special event, conducted pursuant to subsection C7 of this section.
      7.   Special Off-Sale Restrictions: A civic, charitable, educational,
fraternal, or veterans' organization holding a special event license pursuant
to subsections C4b, C5, and C6 of this section shall only sell wine, malt
beverages, or alcoholic beverages, as applicable to the license, that have been
donated by members of the public. Any donated alcoholic beverage must have been
purchased by the donor from a licensed South Dakota retailer. (Ord. 2533, 4-4-
2016)
4-2-8: FULL SERVICE RESTAURANT ON-SALE LICENSE:
The City may issue additional on-sale licenses for full service restaurants
pursuant to South Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-110 et seq.
   A.   Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this
section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where
the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
   BAR: Any permanently installed counter within the restaurant area from which
alcoholic beverages are regularly served to customers by a person who is
tending bar or drawing or mixing alcoholic beverages.
   FULL SERVICE RESTAURANT: Any restaurant at which a waiter or waitress
delivers food and drink offered from a printed food menu to patrons at tables,
booths, or the bar. Any restaurant that only serves fry orders or foodstuffs
such as sandwiches, hamburgers, or salads is not a full service restaurant.
   RESTAURANT: Any area in a building maintained, advertised, and held out to
the public as a place where individually priced meals are prepared and served
primarily for consumption in such area and where not more than forty percent
(40%) of the gross revenue of the restaurant is derived from the sale of
alcohol or alcoholic beverages. The restaurant shall have a dining room or
rooms, a kitchen, and the number and kinds of employees necessary for the
preparing, cooking, and serving of meals.
   B.   License Application Requirements; Documentation: An applicant for a
full service restaurant on-sale license shall provide sufficient documentation
to the City with an application form provided by the Municipality to prove that
the primary source of revenue from the operation of the restaurant will be
derived from the sale of prepared food and nonalcoholic beverages and not from
the sale of alcoholic beverages. The renewal of a full service restaurant on-
sale license is conditioned upon the applicant satisfying all State
requirements for renewal. The supporting documentation concerning the primary
source of revenue submitted pursuant to this section is confidential.
   C.   Advertising Restriction: A restaurant that has a full service
restaurant on-sale license may only be advertised or held out to the public as
primarily a food eating establishment.
   D.   Annual Reports: The full service restaurant on-sale licensee shall
submit an annual report and supporting documentation to the City on forms
provided by the City of the annual sales of the full service restaurant, which
includes an oath verifying the validity of the information provided in the
report. The report and the supporting documentation submitted pursuant to this
section are confidential. The report shall contain the annual gross revenues of
the licensee for the following categories:
      1.   Food and nonalcoholic beverage sales; and
      2.   Alcoholic beverages sales.
   E.   License Renewals: When renewing a full service restaurant on- sale
license, the City shall condition the license renewal upon receiving
documentation that not more than forty percent (40%) of gross sales from the
preceding twelve (12) months operation of the full service restaurant is
derived from the sale of alcohol or alcoholic beverages.
   F.   Only Retail, On-Sale Service Permitted: A full service restaurant on-
sale licensee may only serve alcoholic beverages for on premises consumption in
the bar and dining room area of the restaurant.
   G.   Smoking Prohibited: No licensee that has a full service restaurant on-
sale license may allow smoking on the licensed premises.
   H.   Full Service Restaurant License Fees:
      1.   The license fee charged for full service restaurant on-sale licenses
shall be established by resolution of the City at or above the current fair
market value of the license pursuant to South Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-117.
      2.   The license fee shall be initially established by resolution within
ninety (90) days of the initial adoption of this section. Subsequent changes in
the license fee shall not be made for a period of ten (10) years from the
effective date of this section unless a population growth that is reported by
the Federal decennial census requires an increase in the fee.
   I.   Registry Of Full Service Restaurant On-Sale Licensees: The City will
maintain a registry of each on-sale license that is being offered for sale. The
burden of registering with the City a license being offered for sale rests on
the licensee. The City will provide a copy of the registry to anyone who
requests a new full service restaurant on-sale license. Prior to the issuance
of a new license, the applicant shall submit an affidavit showing that there is
no on-sale license on the registry or that the applicant is unable to purchase
the on-sale license at fair market value and on terms satisfactory to both the
potential buyer and seller.
   J.   Issuance Of New Full Service Restaurant Licenses Restricted: The City
may only issue a new license pursuant to this section if no on-sale license is
on the registry or a person desiring to purchase an on-sale license listed on
the registry provides documentation showing that the person is unable to
purchase the on-sale license at the price established in subsection H of this
section and on terms satisfactory to both the potential buyer and seller. The
price of any on-sale license registered as for sale with the City shall be sold
at the current fair market price set by the City pursuant to a resolution
adopted in accordance with subsection I of this section.
   K.   Provision Of Pricing Information: Each licensee who owns an on-sale
license as of January 1, 2008, and purchased or had the license transferred to
such licensee at any time between January 1, 2003, and January 1, 2008, shall
provide to the Finance Officer the information required by State law within
thirty (30) days of request by the Finance Officer of the City of Mitchell.
(Ord. 2387, 12-19-2011)
4-2-9: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished
as provided in the general penalty in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (2005 Code; amd. Ord. 2387, 12-19-2011)
ARTICLE A. OUTDOOR DINING AREAS
SECTION:
4-2A-1: Sale And Consumption Of Alcoholic Wine Beverages On Sidewalk
4-2A-1: SALE AND CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOLIC WINE BEVERAGES ON SIDEWALK:
   A.   Allowed Subject To Provisions: The sale and consumption of alcoholic
wine beverages is authorized on sidewalks and other public right of way
abutting licensed premises in the central business district of the city of
Mitchell in outdoor dining areas, subject to the provisions hereinafter set
forth.
   B.   Definitions:
    OUTDOOR DINING AREA: An area on a public sidewalk in front of and adjacent
to a business sometimes referred to as a sidewalk cafe, where food is sold,
served or consumed.
   PERMIT (And Words Derivative Thereof): An authorization granted by the city
governing body for the sale of alcoholic wine beverages upon an outdoor dining
area, subject to such limitations as the governing body shall impose.
   SIDEWALK: All that area legally open to the public use as a public right of
way between the curb line and the public right of way boundary along the
abutting property.
   C.   Application Procedures:
      1.   A permit under this section may be granted for service of alcoholic
wine beverages only.
      2.   Issuance of a permit under this section shall be limited to areas
within the city zoned as central business district only.
      3.   No permit under this section shall be granted for use during the
period of time known in the city of Mitchell as "Corn Palace week".
      4.   An application for a permit to sell, serve and consume alcoholic
wine beverage in an outdoor dining area shall be made on such forms as
prescribed by the city, by the owner whose business is adjacent to the sidewalk
upon which the alcoholic wine beverages are requested to be sold, served or
consumed.
      5.   Each permit shall terminate on December 31 of each year and will be
personal to the permittee only and is not transferable in any manner.
      6.   The application will state that the request is being made for the
sale, service and consumption of alcoholic wine beverages in the outdoor dining
area and applicant will acknowledge that the permit is subject to all terms of
South Dakota Codified Laws 35-4-77.1.
      7.   The fee for said application will be established from time to time
by resolution of the governing body of the city, and shall be paid to the city
finance office prior to exercise of rights granted in a permit.
      8.   The hours of operation requested for the sale, service and
consumption of alcoholic wine beverages for the outdoor dining area shall be
stated in the application.
      9.   A site plan shall be submitted with the application noting the
general area of where outdoor furniture will be located upon the public right
of way.
      10.   The governing body of the city in considering any application for a
permit shall consider the impact of each proposed permit upon public property,
public investments, public rights of access and way, and to business owners,
property owners and residents. The governing body of the city reserves the
right as steward of public right of way, to limit, prohibit or place conditions
on nonpublic uses of the public right of way.
      11.   The applicant requesting the permit by making such request and
exercising rights which are granted in a permit, assumes all liability
associated with the sidewalk cafe activities and shall hold the city of
Mitchell "harmless" in matters associated with the operation of said cafe.
   D.   Insurance: Prior to exercise of any right granted in respect to a
permit, the owner of the applicable business shall furnish and maintain in
effect at all times the permit remains issued, a policy of insurance protecting
the applicant and the city from all claims for damage to property or bodily
injury, including death, which may arise from operations under the permit in
the outdoor dining area. The insurance policy shall list or endorse the city of
Mitchell as additional insured and carry minimum liability limits of at least
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. The endorsement shall
provide that the policy shall not be terminated or canceled prior to the
termination of the outdoor dining area use without thirty (30) days' written
notice to the city.
   E.   Regulations:
      1.   The preparation of food upon the sidewalk is prohibited excepting
cases where garnishments are added to food. In respect to events where a city
street or sidewalk has been closed in conjunction with the event, food
preparation upon the sidewalk may be allowed if permitted pursuant to the
application process for the event.
      2.   No fixtures or devices on which food or beverages are sold or
consumed shall be attached to the sidewalk or other public area.
      3.   In no case will outdoor dining or sales, service or consumption of
alcoholic wine beverage occur upon public right of way other than that which is
adjacent to the building or structure from which the business providing the
outdoor food and beverage service operates as its permanent place of business,
unless excepted by the governing body in a permit.
      4.   Furniture and other personal property shall not block regulatory
signs, crosswalks or intersections; shall be compliant with all provisions of
this code; and shall be sufficiently lit during times of low light in order to
provide for safe pedestrian passage alongside the outdoor dining area.
Furniture and personal property upon the public right of way shall not have
sharp edges, protrusions or other features which may be hazardous to the
public.
      5.   All equipment used for food and alcoholic wine beverage sales,
service or consumption shall be removed from public right of way during hours
the applicable business is not in operation.
      6.   The business owner or operator which conducts outdoor food or
alcoholic wine beverage sales, service and consumption shall keep the outdoor
service area clean of garbage, trash, paper, cups, cans or litter.
      7.   Outdoor food and alcoholic wine beverage sales, service and
consumption upon any public right of way shall be located so that such sales,
service and consumption does not impede, endanger or interfere with pedestrian
traffic. Furniture and other personal property shall be located so that they do
not impede, endanger or interfere with pedestrian traffic. A clear passage
space of a minimum of six feet (6') of passage shall be allowed for pedestrian
traffic.
      8.   Signs used to advertise the outdoor food or alcoholic wine beverage
sales, service and consumption, and the outdoor dining area shall meet all
applicable sign regulations and be secured so that they are not dislodged
during windy or stormy weather.
      9.   All outdoor dining areas, if within any type of enclosure or fence,
must have at least one opening for ingress and egress directly to the outside.
      10.   The permit may be revoked for failure to maintain the standards
required for the permit. A notice of intent to revoke the permit shall be given
in writing ten (10) days prior to actual revocation and shall specify the area
or areas of continued failure to meet requirements and maintain conditions the
city may have imposed. If, during that period, proof of compliance is made by
the holder of the permit, the permit shall be continued in force.
      11.   The permit may be temporarily suspended by the public works
director if the public interest requires use of the right of way for a public
event, construction, repair or any other purpose. (Ord. 2437, 6-3-2013)
CHAPTER 3
AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
4-3-1: Licenses Required
4-3-2: Bond Requirements
4-3-3: Exemptions
4-3-1: LICENSES REQUIRED:
   A.   Open Air Shows: No person shall conduct, operate or exhibit any moving
picture show, theatrical performance or other exhibition of skill or amusement,
circuses, menageries, wild west shows or carnivals, in any tent or on any
vacant lot or on any public grounds and not in a building or enclosure built in
conformity with this code or other ordinances for such purpose, without a
license. The license fee shall be as established from time to time by
resolution of the city council. (1984 Code § 20-11; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Theaters: No person shall conduct or operate any opera house, theater
or moving picture show without securing a license therefor. The license fee
shall be as established from time to time by resolution of the city council.
(2005 Code)
4-3-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Before any license shall be issued to any circus or carnival, such applicant
shall deposit with the finance officer a cash bond in the sum of five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00) conditioned upon the licensee leaving all public grounds,
ways or places used or occupied by such licensee in a clean, sanitary and
undamaged condition. Otherwise, such sum shall be forfeited to the city. (1984
Code § 20-13; amd. 2005 Code)
4-3-3: EXEMPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to any lecture or exhibition for a purely literary
or scientific character nor to any concert or entertainment given for charity
or for public benefit. (1984 Code § 20-14)
CHAPTER 4
RIDE SERVICE COMPANIES
SECTION:
4-4-1: Purpose
4-4-2: Definitions
4-4-3: Ride Service Company License Requirements
4-4-4: Financial Responsibility
4-4-5: Notification To Chief Of Police
4-4-6: Rate Regulation And Receipts
4-4-7: Vehicle Requirements
4-4-8: Out Of Town VFH Companies And TNC Driver Vehicles
4-4-9: Revocation Of License
4-4-10: Dollar Amounts To Be Set By Resolution
4-4-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish rules and regulations for ride
service companies which promote and protect the health, safety, and welfare of
the general public. (Ord. O2019-21, 10-7-2019)
4-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
