8-1-1: GRADES, WIDTHS AND MINIMUM STANDARDS OF STREETS:
   A.   Grades: All previous ordinances of the City establishing grades of
streets, avenues and alleys in various parts of the City are retained and
continued, subject only to such extensions, supplements and interpretations as
appear from the records of the Director of Public Works, which records and maps
are incorporated herein by reference and adopted as a part of the official
record of the grades of streets, avenues and alleys of the City.
   B.   Widths:
      1.   Reconstruction: At such time as any street within the jurisdictional
limits of the City is reconstructed, it shall be reconstructed with a minimum
width of thirty six feet (36') or the width previously existing, whichever is
greater; except, that local residential side streets may be reconstructed to
the minimum width of their previously existing dimensions.
      2.   New Construction: Streets newly constructed shall be built at a
minimum width of forty feet (40').
A "local residential side street" is defined as a street to which the majority
of the platted lots fronting thereon abut as side yards and not as front yards
and which street is not classified as a collector street, principal arterial
street or minor arterial street, as referenced in the street master plan
adopted by the City.
   C.   Minimum Standard Cross Section Of Streets:
      1.   Residential Street Section: The minimum cross sectional area of a
residential street in Mitchell shall be not less than eight inches (8") of base
course plus three inches (3") of asphalt concrete.
      2.   Commercial Street Section: The minimum cross sectional area of a
commercial street in Mitchell shall be not less than twelve inches (12") of
base course plus four inches (4") of asphalt.
The above minimum standards may be increased by the Director of Public Works
for a particular street if determined to be necessary by testing or design
experience. Fabric separation of subbase material and base course may also be
ordered by the Director of Public Works based upon conditions in the field or
by testing or design experience. (Ord. 2421, 1-7-2013)
8-1-2: ASSESSMENTS FOR IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Street And Alley Improvements: Whenever the City Council shall cause to
be opened, widened, extended, graded, graveled, surfaced with oil or other
bituminous material, paved, repaved, street lighting equipment to be erected
in, curbed, guttered, drained or otherwise improved, any street, alley or
public way, it may provide for the cost thereof to be paid by special
assessment against the abutting property, according to law 1 . All such special
assessments shall be imposed in strict conformance with the applicable laws of
the State. (1984 Code § 34-52)
   B.   Sidewalk Improvement: Whenever the City Council shall cause to be
constructed, reconstructed or repaired any sidewalk, it may provide for the
cost thereof to be paid by special assessment against the abutting property,
according to law. All such special assessments shall be imposed in strict
conformance with the applicable laws of the State. (1984 Code § 34-53)
 
Notes
1 1. SDCL § 9-45-39.
8-1-3: USE OF PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Building Materials: No person shall place or keep any building
equipment or material on any street, alley or public ground without securing a
permit therefor and complying with the provisions of this subsection.
      1.   The director of public works, with approval of the chief of police
or designated representative, may grant a written permit, for a time therein
limited and not exceeding three (3) months, to any person to keep building
equipment and materials on any street, alley or public place adjacent to any
lot whereon such building material is about to be used. For good cause, such
permit may be extended.
      2.   Such permit shall not authorize the obstruction of more than two-
thirds (2/3) of the widths of the sidewalk or more than one- third (1/3) of the
roadway adjacent to such lot nor shall such materials be so kept as to obstruct
the free flow of water in gutters of such street. (1984 Code § 34-4)
      3.   The person to whom a permit is issued shall keep posted at such
place adequate warning lights, designed to the standards of the "Manual On
Uniform Traffic Control Devices" for the protection of the traveling public,
and shall, before the expiration of the time limit in such permit or extension
thereof, remove all such material and rubbish from such sidewalk, street, alley
or public place. (1984 Code § 34-4; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Merchandise On Sidewalk: No person shall place any goods or merchandise
for sale or exhibition upon any sidewalk; except, that for the purpose of
loading or unloading, such articles may be placed upon the outer side of
sidewalk for such time as may be necessary to load or unload the same, but in
no instance shall any such articles be left upon the sidewalk in the nighttime
or in such way as to obstruct the sidewalk. The city council may authorize
exceptions to this subsection; provided, that any such exception and the
reasons therefor are entered into the minutes of the city council. (1984 Code §
34-23)
   C.   Newsracks On Public Ways And Property:
      1.   No newsrack or newspaper vending box or stand shall be placed or
allowed to remain upon the Corn Palace or Corn Palace parking lot premises,
city hall or city hall parking lot premises or the sidewalks adjacent thereto
(block 6, Rowley's first addition to the city of Mitchell, Davison County,
South Dakota).
      2.   No person shall suffer or allow any newsrack, newspaper rack or
stand to be placed upon any sidewalk or public way in the city in a manner or
location which unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian
or vehicular traffic or creates a hazard to the persons or property within the
city or causes or creates a nuisance.
      3.   No newsrack may be fastened to or secured upon any public way or
public property and may not be claimed or fastened to any public light pole,
street sign or other publicly owned fixture or structure. (Ord. 1535, 7-21-
1986)
      4.   The penalty for violation of any of the provisions of this
subsection and for each of said violations shall be as provided in the general
penalty in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day a violation of this subsection exists shall be
deemed to be a new and separate violation. (Ord. 1535, 7-21-1986; amd. 2005
Code)
   D.   Awnings Over Sidewalks 1 : (Rep. by Ord. 2422, 1-21-2013)
   E.   Service Stations And Pumps On Public Ways: No person shall locate,
construct or maintain any gasoline or oil filling station or pump, in whole or
in part, upon any street, parking or sidewalk or under any public right of way.
(1984 Code § 34-13; amd. 2005 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 9-4-5K4 of this code.
8-1-4: DAMAGE TO PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Moving Things Over Public Ways:
      1.   No person shall drag over any of the streets or alleys of the city
any branches of trees, chain or other material which shall come in contact with
and drag upon such roadway. This subsection A1 shall not apply to machines used
in maintaining the streets and alleys, under the supervision of the director of
public works. (1984 Code § 34-7)
      2.   No person shall move any article over any street or alley within the
city unless such article is entirely supported on wheels, except when such
operation is specifically authorized by the Director of Public Works. (1984
Code § 34-24)
   B.   Vehicles With Lugs: No person shall haul, drive or convey across or
upon any of the paved or bituminous surfaced streets, alleys or crosswalks of
the City any engine, tractor, machine or vehicle having lugs, cogs or spikes on
the wheels or tracks thereof without first having planked such pavement in a
manner sufficient to prevent damage to such pavement. (1984 Code § 34-6)
   C.   Fires On Pavements: No person shall burn or permit to be burned any
material of any kind upon any paved or bituminous surfaced street, alley or
public place 1 . (1984 Code § 34-11)
   D.   Use Of Saltwater Mixtures: No person shall deposit or cause to be
deposited, directly or indirectly any salt or saltwater brine upon any
sidewalk, street or alley, except for the placing of salt upon sidewalks and
pavements when it is necessary to protect pedestrians from slipping on the ice.
(1984 Code § 34-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  5-4-4 of this Code.
8-1-5: OBSTRUCTIONS:
   A.   Vehicle Obstructions: No person shall place, leave or keep on any
street, road, alley, sidewalk or other public ground any vehicle, except when
the same shall be in actual use or parked as provided by this Code 1  or other
Traffic Ordinances or any other article, substance or material which may
obstruct the free use of such street, road, alley, sidewalk or public ground.
(1984 Code § 34-1)
   B.   Train Obstructions: No railroad company, engineer, conductor or other
employee of such company shall cause or allow any locomotive engine, car or
train to stop or remain on any street or railroad crossing for a longer period
than five (5) minutes at any one time; provided, that in case of accident at
any such place, a reasonable time shall be allowed to remove any obstruction
caused thereby. (1984 Code § 34-10)
   C.   Sight Triangle At Intersections 2 : (Rep. by Ord. 2422, 1-21-2013)
   D.   Crowds Obstructing Public Ways: It shall be unlawful for persons to
gather in crowds or groups or for any person to stand on any public street or
sidewalk in such a manner as to obstruct free passage thereon or to annoy other
persons passing along the same, and any police officer is authorized to
disperse any crowd or group or to cause the removal of any person violating the
provisions of this subsection and to summarily arrest any person in case of
refusal to obey any reasonable direction or preventing annoyance to any
passerby on any public street or sidewalk. (1984 Code § 34-20)
 
Notes
1 2. See title 7, chapter 4 of this Code.
2 1. See subsection 9-4-5I of this Code.
8-1-6: PROHIBITED AND RESTRICTED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Depositing Rubbish Or Injurious Material On Public Ways: No person
shall place, throw or deposit or cause to be thrown, placed or deposited on any
street, alley or public place any of the following:
      1.   Any stone, brick, gravel, crushed rock, asphalt, tar, oil or grease
or any other substance injurious to pavement.
      2.   Any ashes, rubbish, manure, carcass of any dead animal or any other
filthy or offensive matter or thing. This subsection shall not apply to
building material placed on streets or provided by this Code or other
ordinance. (1984 Code § 34-3)
   B.   Leaving Rubbish Or Sweepings Within Business District: No person,
except City employees actually engaged in cleaning streets or alleys, shall
deposit or leave in any street or alley within the Business District of the
City any sweepings or rubbish. (1984 Code § 34-22)
   C.   Tampering With Public Ways And Property: No person shall injure or
remove any pavement, sidewalk, crosswalk, drain or sewer or dig any hole, ditch
or drains in any street, alley or public ground or remove any of the gravel,
sand or soil therefrom, except when authorized by the Director of Public Works.
(1984 Code § 34-5)
   D.   Vehicles On Parkings Or Sidewalks: See subsection
7-3-8B of this Code. (Ord. O2019-03, 4-15-2019, eff. 7-1-2019)
8-1-7: SIDEWALK SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL:
8-1-7-1: DUTY TO REMOVE IN GENERAL:
The occupant or owner of any premises in the City shall remove all snow and ice
from the entire width of all adjacent public sidewalks within forty eight (48)
hours after the fall of snow or the formation of ice on such sidewalk. Adjacent
sidewalk shall include all sidewalk located in public right-of-way and between
the property line and the nearest roadway. Adjacent sidewalk shall also include
all sidewalk located on private property but within a sidewalk easement. No
occupant or owner may be relieved of this duty except by application of section
8-1-7-2 of this section
8-1-7. (Ord. O2018-08, 9-17-2018)
8-1-7-2: SPECIAL REMOVAL AREAS DESIGNATED:
For the purposes of maintaining aesthetics, lengthening the useful life of
sidewalks, and establishing certain priority routes for pedestrian travel, the
City Council may designate special removal areas by resolution. In such special
removal areas, the general duty under section
8-1-7-1 of this section
8-1-7 shall not apply and the City of Mitchell shall be responsible for
sidewalk snow and ice removal. (Ord. O2018-08, 9-17-2018)
8-1-7-3: REMOVAL BY CITY UPON VIOLATION:
If the owner or occupant of any premises shall fail, neglect, or refuse to
comply with section
8-1-7-1 of this section
8-1-7, it shall be the duty of the Director of Public Works to remove or cause
the removal of such snow or ice. Such owner or occupant shall be responsible
for all costs of removal in addition to any fines that may apply. The City may
contract with private persons to accomplish the removal of snow or ice as is
required by this section. (Ord. O2018-08, 9-17-2018)
8-1-7-4: COSTS FOR REMOVAL:
   A.   Account Of Cost: The Director of Public Works shall cause to be kept an
account of the costs for snow and ice removal under section
8-1-7-3 of this section
8-1-7 as to each lot or parcel of land so cleared. Such accounting shall be
certified to the Finance Officer following every snow season.
   B.   Estimate And Notice Of Assessment: The Finance Officer shall prepare an
estimate of the assessment against each lot for snow and ice removal to include
the expense of levying such special assessment against each lot. The Finance
Officer shall cause to be published in the official newspaper the assessment
roll, together with a notice of the time and place when the City Council will
meet for the purpose of considering such assessment roll. Such notice shall be
published once a week for two (2) successive weeks prior to the date of the
hearing.
   C.   Approval By City Council; Filing Of Assessment: Upon the day so named,
the City Council shall meet, and if it finds the estimate correct, it shall
approve the same by resolution, or if not correct, it shall correct or modify
the same and approve the same as modified or corrected and file such assessment
roll with the Finance Officer.
   D.   Lien Against Property: From the date of the approval and filing of such
assessment roll with the Finance Officer, the same shall be and become a
special lien against the various pieces of property described in the assessment
roll and shall be collected in like manner as special assessments for public
improvements are now collected. (Ord. O2018-08, 9-17-2018)
8-1-8: SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE:
The owner or occupant of any lot or private ground abutting upon any public
sidewalk shall not allow rubbish, debris or obstruction of any kind to be or
remain on such sidewalk along such abutting property. (1984 Code § 34-9)
8-1-9: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, in addition
to other penalties, be liable for any damage caused by such violation. (1984
Code § 34-14)
ARTICLE A. SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION 1
SECTION:
8-1A-1: Supervision
8-1A-2: Permit Requirements
8-1A-3: Design Standards
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  9-2-3 of this code for required new sidewalks.
8-1A-1: SUPERVISION:
The construction of all sidewalks, street or alley crossings within or upon the
streets or alleys in the city shall at all times be under the supervision of
the director of public works. (1984 Code § 34-26)
8-1A-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   No person shall construct any sidewalk or street or alley crossing
without first having secured a permit from the director of public works.
   B.   Such permit shall be in the form approved by the city council and shall
state the date when the permit is issued, a detailed and definite description
of the location where the walk or crossing is to be built, the name of the
person intending to construct such walk or crossing and a statement to be
signed by such person or by a duly authorized representative that he will
conform to all the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city in the
execution of the work. (1984 Code § 34-26)
8-1A-3: DESIGN STANDARDS:
   A.   Compliance With Provisions: All sidewalks, streets and alley crossings
in the city shall be constructed of the material and in the manner provided by
city specifications on file with the director of public works. (1984 Code § 34-
26; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Thickness: Except as may be otherwise provided, all sidewalks, except
street and alley crosswalks, shall be not less than four inches (4") in
thickness. Street and alley crosswalks shall be six inches (6") in thickness.
(1984 Code § 34-37)
   C.   Width: The width of all sidewalks shall be as provided in this
subsection.
      1.   The width of sidewalks shall extend from the property line to the
curb at the following places:
         a.   On Main Street from the right of way of the Chicago, Milwaukee,
St. Paul and Pacific Railway Company to the right of way of the Chicago, St.
Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railway Company.
         b.   On Railroad Street from South Kimball Street to South Sanborn
Boulevard.
         c.   On First Avenue from South Kimball Street to Duff Street.
         d.   On Second Avenue, Oscar Howe Avenue and Fourth Avenue from North
Lawler Street to North Rowley Street.
         e.   On Fifth and Sixth Avenues from the alley between Main and Lawler
Streets to the alley between Main and Rowley Streets.
      2.   Sidewalks in all other parts of the city shall be five feet (5') in
width; except, that the sidewalk in front of any property may be, at the option
of the owner, extended from the property line to the curb. (1984 Code § 34-38)
   D.   Location: Sidewalks shall be placed on street right of way six inches
(6") from the property line. (1984 Code § 34-39)
ARTICLE B. EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
8-1B-1: Supervision
8-1B-2: Permit Requirements
8-1B-3: Fees
8-1B-4: Barricades And Lights
8-1B-5: Construction Regulations
8-1B-6: Guarantee
8-1B-1: SUPERVISION:
The director of public works shall supervise all excavations made for any
purpose in the streets, alleys, parkings or public grounds in the city and
shall require that all excavations be refilled in the manner specified in this
article, and shall have the authority to regulate the width of trenches into
which no people will enter. (1984 Code §§ 34-42, 34-47)
8-1B-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit:
      1.   Required: No person shall make or cause to be made any excavation in
or under any street, parking, sidewalk, alley or public ground or remove any
earth, paving, gravel, curb and gutter or other material therefrom without
having first obtained a written permit therefor from the director of public
works.
      2.   Fees: In addition to the fees currently in existence for said
excavation permit, additional fees shall be charged for curb and gutter and
other concrete which excavator shall remove or tunnel under, thus weakening
said concrete, as follows:
 
Concrete curb and gutter  $30.00 per linear foot (10 foot minimum)
Concrete flat work:        
   4 inches and under  $4.00 per square foot
   6 inches            $6.00 per square foot
   Over 6 inches       $6.00 per square foot plus $1.00 per square foot per
                           inch of thickness over 6 inches
 
      3.   Setting Of Fees By Resolution: Fees for excavation permit, including
asphalt, base, concrete shall hereafter be set by resolution of the city
council. (Ord. 2283, 7-21-2008)
   B.   Application For Permit: Any person desiring to make any excavation in
public property shall make a written application to the director of public
works, in which application shall be stated:
      1.   The legal description of the lots adjacent to which such excavation
is to be made.
      2.   The building number of the lots adjacent to which such excavation is
to be made, if applicable.
      3.   The dimensions of such excavation.
      4.   The purpose for which such excavation is to be made.
      5.   Whether or not such applicant filed a bond with the finance officer
as required by this article.
      6.   The amount of bituminous pavement replacement fee if replacement
will be done by the city. (1984 Code § 34-41)
   C.   Qualifications: Excavation permits will be issued to licensed plumbers
and to the public utility companies under franchise from the city. (1984 Code §
34-42)
   D.   Bond: The city may require that bond be posted for the purpose of
guaranteeing that excavations are properly backfilled and cleaned up and that
the fees are paid. The amount of the bond shall be five thousand dollars
($5,000.00). The city may in its discretion waive the posting of bond. (1984
Code § 34-42; amd. 2005 Code)
   E.   Issuance Or Denial Of Permit:
      1.   If the director of public works finds that such excavation can be
made with no undue inconvenience to the public and that the applicant is
qualified to make such excavation and has made the required deposit with the
finance officer or filed a proper bond, as required by this article, then he
shall issue to such applicant a written permit to make such excavation.
      2.   If the director of public works finds that the excavator is not
compacting the backfill to ninety five percent (95%) of maximum dry density, as
determined by test method AASHTO T-99 or other methods approved by the director
of public works, or if the backfill on previous trenches settles or if the
paving is improperly replaced, he may refuse to issue any further permits for
street excavation until the unsatisfactory excavations are satisfactorily
compacted and all paving is properly replaced. (1984 Code § 34-44)
8-1B-3: FEES:
Where it is necessary to make any street excavation, there shall be deposited
with the finance officer an amount established in the schedule adopted from
time to time by resolution of the city council. A fee for each separate
excavation will be charged according to the schedule, and the fees shall be
doubled for excavations made between November 1 and March 31. The charges for
excavations in concrete streets shall be twice the rate for bituminous streets.
For purposes of computing the square footage for the required charges, any cut
narrower than twelve inches (12") shall be considered to be a twelve inch (12")
cut. (1984 Code § 34-45; amd. 2005 Code)
8-1B-4: BARRICADES AND LIGHTS:
Any person receiving a permit to make excavations in or upon any street, alley,
parking or public ground shall, during the progress and continuance of work,
erect and maintain around the same both by day and by night, suitable guards,
fences, lanterns and signals so as to prevent injury to persons, animals or
vehicles on account of such excavations. Such lanterns or other lights shall be
kept lighted from sundown to sunrise. Traffic signing shall be to the standards
of the manual of uniform traffic control devices, a copy of which is on file
with the director of public works. (1984 Code § 34-48; amd. 2005 Code)
8-1B-5: CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Guard Protection Required: No person, owner or occupant of any lot
shall make or cause to be made any excavation on a lot adjacent to any street,
alley, parking, public ground or traveled road or roadway, unless the same
shall be securely guarded so as to prevent the injury to any person or animal
passing along such lot. (1984 Code § 34-49)
   B.   Excavations For Cellars Under Sidewalks: No person having or erecting
any building abutting upon any street, avenue or alley may excavate under the
sidewalk for the purpose of constructing a cellar or basement under the
sidewalk in front of or adjoining such building. (1984 Code § 34-51)
   C.   Straight Edges: Where existing pavement is removed, the excavator
shall, by sawing or other satisfactory method, ensure that the pavement edges
are straight and vertical.
   D.   Paving And Patches:
      1.   The permittee may replace bituminous paving with hot asphalt
concrete bituminous mix if he has experienced personnel and proper equipment
and demonstrates a record of smooth, well done patching. The edges of the
existing paving and the gravel base course shall be primed in a manner
satisfactory to the director of public works before replacing paving.
      2.   If the permittee replaces the bituminous paving, he will maintain
the street excavation until he has replaced the paving. The paving shall be
placed as soon as hot bituminous concrete mix is available. (1984 Code § 34-45)
   E.   Refilling Excavation: Any person making an excavation shall, when the
same has been completed, promptly and without delay refill the same as provided
in this subsection.
      1.   In refilling any excavation, the earth shall be thoroughly tamped as
the refilling progresses. The earth shall be thoroughly tamped in successive
layers in such manner that the fill is compacted to ninety five percent (95%)
of the maximum dry density as determined by test method AASHTO T-99 or other
methods approved by the director of public works.
      2.   In refilling excavations through base course or pavement, the
contractor shall thoroughly clean up all excess material and shall clean out
foreign material in the trench to the depth of the pavement but not less than
an eight inch (8") depth. He shall place base course to pavement level, compact
it thoroughly with water as needed and clean the excess gravel off the
pavement. The gravel for such street excavation will be delivered to the
excavation site by the city at no charge if at least eight (8) hours' notice is
given. (1984 Code § 34-46)
8-1B-6: GUARANTEE:
If, at any time within one year after the issuance of the excavation permit,
the director of public works shall find that the excavator has not properly
backfilled the excavation or has not properly replaced the pavement, he shall
notify the excavator, in writing, that the work shall be put in satisfactory
condition within ten (10) days. If the excavator fails to comply with the
direction of such notice, the director of public works shall have the authority
to cause such work to be put in proper and satisfactory condition and cause the
expense to be borne by the excavator. (1984 Code § 34-43)
ARTICLE C. STREET NAMES AND BUILDING NUMBERS
SECTION:
8-1C-1: Baselines
8-1C-2: Street Names
8-1C-3: Building Numbers
8-1C-1: BASELINES:
   A.   The street named Main Street on the original plat of the city, together
with the extensions of such street, shall continue to be known as Main Street
and shall be the north and south baseline. The following are street names
parallel to Main Street unless otherwise referenced in this section.
   B.   The street named First Avenue on the original plat of the city,
together with the extensions of such street, shall be known as First Avenue and
shall be the east and west baseline. The following street names parallel to
First Avenue unless otherwise referenced in this section. (1984 Code § 34-54;
amd. Ord. 2528, 2-16-2016)
8-1C-2: STREET NAMES:
   A.   Streets Parallel To Main Street:
      1.   All streets parallel to and west from Main Street, in successive
order westward, shall be named throughout their extensions within the city,
except as otherwise provided, as follows: Rowley Street, Duff Street, Sanborn
Boulevard, Edmunds Street, Wisconsin Street, Minnesota Street, Montana Street,
Iowa Street, Isadore Street, Juanita Street, Edgerton Street, Johnson Street
and Ohlman Street.
      2.   All streets parallel to and east from Main Street, in successive
order eastward, shall be named throughout their extensions within the city as
follows: Lawler Street, Kimball Street, Langdon Street, Davison Street, Burr
Street, Capital Street, Winsor Street, Mentzer Street, Gamble Street, Kittridge
Street, Hunter Street, Foster Street, Marshal Street and Taylor Street. (1984
Code § 34-55)
   B.   Street Prefixes:
      1.   North And South: All parts of the streets named in subsection A of
this section extending south of First Avenue shall have "South" prefixed to
their names, and all parts of such streets extending north of First Avenue
shall have "North" prefixed to their names. (1984 Code § 34-56)
      2.   East And West: All parts of the streets named in subsection A of
this section extending east of Main Street shall have "East" prefixed to their
names. All parts of such streets extending west of Main Street shall have
"West" prefixed to their names. (1984 Code § 34-57)
   C.   Avenues Parallel To First Avenue:
      1.   All streets parallel to and north from First Avenue, in successive
order northward, shall be named throughout their extensions within the city as
follows: Second Avenue, Oscar Howe Avenue, Fourth Avenue and so on in numerical
succession until the north limits of the city are reached.
      2.   The street next south of First Avenue and running parallel to the
main track of Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad and extending
from Sanborn Boulevard to Kimball Street shall be named Railroad Avenue.
      3.   The street parallel to and next south of First Avenue shall be named
throughout its extension within the city as Hanson Avenue and the next streets
parallel to and south of Hanson Avenue shall be named throughout their
extension within the city, except those in University Addition, successively
southward, as follows: Ash, Birch, Cedar, Douglas, Elm, Fir, Gum, Hackberry,
Ivy, Juniper, Kay, Linden and Maple. (1984 Code § 34-58)
   D.   Exceptions; Other Designations:
      1.   University Addition: University Addition to the city shall be an
exception to the provisions of this section, and the streets, places, courts,
avenues and boulevards shall retain the names assigned to them as shown on the
original plat of such addition, now of record in the office of the register of
deeds of the county; except:
East University Avenue is hereby changed to McGovern Avenue.
Hurst Street is hereby changed to Hurst Avenue.
Pennington Avenue is hereby changed to South Rowley Street.
Williams Street is hereby changed to Williams Avenue. (Ord. 2206, 6-19-2006;
amd. Ord. 2244, 5-21-2007)
      2.   Harmon Drive At Lake Mitchell: The road meandering around Lake
Mitchell, as shown on the "plat showing extension of the city limits of
Mitchell, South Dakota to include Lake Mitchell", which plat now appears of
record in the office of the register of deeds of the county in volume 4 at page
40 thereof, is hereby named in honor of A.J. Harmon, as follows:
         a.   That part of such road north of Lake Mitchell and extending from
the northeast corner of section 9, township 103 and range 60 to the point where
such road crosses the line between section 6 in such township and range and
section 31, township 104 and range 60 as shown on such plat, shall be known and
designated as North Harmon Drive. (1984 Code § 34-60)
         b.   That part of such road south of Lake Mitchell and extending from
the west end of North Harmon Drive to the point where such road intersects
North Ohlman Street shall be known and designated as West Harmon Drive. (1984
Code § 34-60; amd. 2005 Code)
         c.   That part of such road south of Lake Mitchell and extending from
the point where West Harmon Drive intersects North Ohlman Street to Ohlman
Street at the southeast corner of section 4, township 103, range 60 and within
the area commonly known as Indianhead shall be known as South Harmon Drive.
(1984 Code § 34-60)
   E.   Street Name Changes:
      1.   Indian Village Road: The public roadway within the city heretofore
named and designated as Golf Course Road and south of Lake Mitchell within
section 9, township 103, range 60 shall be renamed and shall hereafter be
designated as Indian Village Road, and all references made to Golf Course Road
in any plat, map or other document filed in any city, county or state office
shall hereafter refer to Indian Village Road. (1984 Code § 34-61)
      2.   Twenty Third Avenue: The public roadway within the city, heretofore
named and designated as Cemetery Road, shall be renamed and shall hereafter be
designated as Twenty Third Avenue and all references made to Cemetery Road in
any plat, map or other document filed in any city, county or state office shall
hereafter refer to Twenty Third Avenue. (1984 Code § 34-62)
      3.   South Anderson Street: The segment of dedicated street right of way
within the city denominated in the approved plat thereof as Wesley Acres Drive,
shall henceforth be named and known as South Anderson Street. (Ord. 1966, 4-3-
2000)
      4.   Charles Avenue: The east and west segment of dedicated street right
of way within the city denominated in the approved plats recorded with the
Davison County register of deeds in book 19 page 7, dated November 6, 2002,
book 19 page 8, dated November 6, 2002, and book 18 page 3, dated thereof, as
Charles Street, shall henceforth be named and known as Charles Avenue. (Ord.
2075, 3-17-2003)
      5.   Quiett Lane: The dedicated street right of way within the city
denominated in the approved plat recorded with the Davis County register of
deeds in book 18, page 3, recorded June 13, 2001, identified as Sam Avenue,
shall henceforth be named and known as Quiett Lane. (Ord. 2107, 12-15-2003)
      6.   South Pepsi Street: The portion of the public right of way now named
"Harriet Street" that is located within the corporate limits of the city of
Mitchell, South Dakota, and abutting block A, Westview Addition; lots 2A and 2,
block B, Westview Addition; lot 2, block C, Westview Addition; block D,
Westview Addition; block A, Jones Addition; north three hundred forty feet
(340') of block C, Jones Addition; is hereby changed to "South Pepsi Street".
(Ord. 2338, 8-2-2010)
      7.   Grassland Drive: That portion of South Langdon Street extending
south of Cabela Drive and north of Spruce Street as referenced in the plat of
lot 5-A and South Langdon Street, being a portion of originally platted lot 5
of Cabela's First Addition to the city of Mitchell, Davison County, South
Dakota, that is filed with the Davison County register of deeds in book 24,
page 34 and any future extension of said street is hereby changed from South
Langdon Street to Grassland Drive. (Ord. 2528, 2-16-2016)
      8.   The public right-of-way now named Home Federal Avenue and dedicated
and identified on the Plat Book 21, Page 5 that is recorded with the Davison
County Register of Deeds is hereby changed to Iverson Avenue. (Ord. O2021-03,
4-5-2021)
   F.   New Additions: All streets in new additions to the city shall be named
as the city council shall indicate, and the names of all streets shall be
placed upon the approved and registered plat shall bear the names indicated
upon the plat unless the same shall be changed by the city council by
ordinance. (1984 Code § 34-63)
   G.   Streets And Roads Outside City Limits: The streets and roads lying
outside of the city limits, but within the city zoning jurisdiction, and which
have not been incorporated in the statewide rural addressing system, which are
hereafter specifically identified, shall be named and identified as follows:
      1.   The north/south section line roadway between sections 11 and 12, 13
and 14, 23 and 24, 25 and 26 and 35 and 36, all within T103N-R60W, shall be
named Gale Road.
      2.   The north/south section line roadway between sections 5 and 6, 7 and
8, 17 and 18, 19 and 20, 29 and 30 and 31 and 32 in T103N-R60W and sections 29
and 30 and 31 and 32 in T104N-R60W, shall be named Navin Road.
      3.   The east/west section line roadway between sections 32, 33, 34 and
the west 1/2 of 35, T103N-R60W and sections 3, 4, 5 and the west 1/2 of 2 in
T104N-R60W, shall be named Willow Street.
      4.   The east/west dedicated roadway between lots 2, 3, 2E, 2F, 2A, 2B,
2C, 4A, 4B and 4C within Cranes Addition (SW1/4 34-T103N-R60W), shall be named
Carl Road.
      5.   The north/south dedicated roadway between lots 2C and lot 4A and the
east west dedicated roadway between lots 4A, 4B, 4C and lot 5, within Cranes
Addition (SW1/4 34-T103N-R60W), shall be named Sunset Road. (Ord. 1748, 10-18-
1993; amd. 2005 Code)
8-1C-3: BUILDING NUMBERS:
   A.   Numbers Required: All residences and business buildings now located or
hereafter constructed or located on properties within the city limits shall be
numbered as provided in this section. (1984 Code § 34-64)
   B.   Baselines For Numbering: Main Street shall be the baseline running
north and south from which shall be determined the proper hundred numeral, as
provided in this section, for blocks on all streets and avenues running east
and west, and First Avenue shall be the baseline running east and west from
which shall be determined the proper hundred numerical, as provided in this
section, for blocks in all streets running north and south. (1984 Code § 34-65)
      1.   East And West Streets: The numbering of all lots fronting on streets
and avenues running east or west from Main Street shall commence at Main Street
with the numeral "100", odd numbers to be on the south side of the streets and
avenues, the even numbers to be on the north sides of the streets and avenues
and directly opposite the corresponding odd numbers and, thus, alternately to
the end of each block, one hundred (100) numbers being allotted to each block
of frontage, and such numbering shall continue east or west, in successive
order of such blocks, until the east or west limits of such streets and avenues
are reached. (1984 Code § 34-66)
      2.   North And South Streets: The numbering of all lots fronting on
streets running north or south from First Avenue shall commence at First Avenue
with the numeral "100", the odd numbers to be on the west sides of the streets,
the even numbers to be on the east sides of the streets and directly opposite
the corresponding odd numbers and, thus, alternately to the end of each block,
one hundred (100) numbers being allotted to each block of frontage, and such
numbering shall continue north and south in successive order of such blocks
until the north and south limits of such streets are reached. (1984 Code § 34-
67)
   C.   Exceptions; Other Designations:
      1.   Numbering When Section Does Not Govern: The numbering of all lots
fronting on streets, courts, places, avenues and boulevards in the city, not
governed by the provisions of this section shall, except as otherwise provided,
commence with the corners nearest to and proceeding from the baseline provided
in this section, running at right angles to such streets, avenues, courts and
boulevards and shall commence with the numeral "100", the odd numbers to be on
the south and west sides of such streets, courts, places, avenues and
boulevards and the even numbers to be on the north and east sides of such
streets, courts, places, avenues and boulevards directly opposite the
corresponding odd numbers and, thus, alternately to the end of each block, one
hundred (100) numbers being allotted to each block of frontage, and such
numbering shall continue in successive order on such streets, courts, avenues,
places and boulevards until their limits are reached; provided, that wherever
such streets, courts, places, avenues and boulevards are extensions of streets
proceeding from the baselines provided in this section, the number of all
blocks shall commence with the "100" numeral next following that "100" numeral
used in numbering the last blocks of the streets of which such streets, courts,
places, avenues and boulevards are extensions. (1984 Code § 34-68)
      2.   Mitchell Boulevard: Mitchell Boulevard in University Addition shall
be an exception to the provisions of this section. The numbering of all lots
fronting on this boulevard shall, at the point where it meets University
Boulevard, commence with the numeral "600", the odd numbers to be on the right
hand side of the boulevard and the even numbers to be on the left hand side of
the boulevard and opposite the corresponding odd numbers and, thus, alternately
to the end of each block, one hundred (100) numbers being allotted to each
block of frontage, and such numbering shall continue in successive order
throughout the length of such boulevard. (1984 Code § 34-69)
      3.   Subdivisions At Lake Mitchell: All residences and business buildings
constructed or located on properties within the city and upon lots or
subdivisions located and laid out at Lake Mitchell shall be numbered as
hereinafter provided:
         a.   Lot number 1, Bayside Subdivision, shall hereafter by known as
North Harmon Drive number 2 and each lot hereafter of the Bayside Subdivision
shall be numbered by consecutive even numeral marking and the address shall be
North Harmon Drive.
         b.   Sunset Point Subdivision number 1 shall be designated as North
Harmon Drive number 98, and each succeeding lot of Sunset Point Subdivision
shall be numbered by consecutive even numeral marking as herein before
designated.
         c.   Indianhead Subdivision lot number one shall carry the designation
South Harmon Drive number 1, and each succeeding lot shall be numbered by
consecutive odd numeral marking throughout the entire Indianhead Subdivision.
         d.   Nels Jensen Subdivision lot number 1 shall carry the designation
of West Harmon Drive number 1, and each succeeding lot shall be numbered by
consecutive odd numeral marking. (1984 Code § 34-72)
      4.   Grassland Drive: That portion of South Langdon Street extending
south of Cabela Drive and north of Spruce Street as referenced in the plat of
lot 5-A and South Langdon Street, being a portion of originally platted lot 5
of Cabela's First Addition to the city of Mitchell, Davison County, South
Dakota, that is filed with the Davison County register of deeds in book 24,
page 34 and any future extension of said street is hereby changed from South
Langdon Street to Grassland Drive is an exception to the numbering set forth in
subsections 8-1C-3A and B of this section. The address range in this street
shall be the 1900 block; however individual buildings may be numbered to
accommodate a campus complex. (Ord. 2528, 2-16-2016)
   D.   Assigning Numbers:
      1.   One number shall be provided for each twenty five foot (25')
frontage on all streets and avenues within the city beginning with the corner
nearest to and proceeding from the baselines provided in this section.
      2.   All buildings coming under the provisions of this section shall take
the numbers determined by the frontages on which they stand. Fractional numbers
may be used to determine numbers for additional ground entrances where the
provisions of this section do not provide for such numbering.
      3.   In cases where there is any doubt about the proper number to be
assigned to any block of twenty five feet (25') of frontage, the director of
public works shall act as a referee and be final authority. He shall be
governed in his rulings by the general provisions for this section. (1984 Code
§ 34-70)
   E.   Number Specifications; Maintenance:
      1.   Numbers for buildings as provided in this section shall be composed
of figures not less than three inches (3") in height and one-half inch (1/2")
in width and shall be made or painted on glass or some metallic substance.
      2.   It is hereby made the duty of the owner and the persons in charge of
any building to place and maintain the numbers as provided in this section.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully remove, deface,
obscure or destroy any number upon a building. (1984 Code § 34-71)
CHAPTER 2
TREES AND SHRUBS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Permitted Trees
8-2-2: Injury Or Damage Prohibited
8-2-3: Trimming
8-2-4: Removal Of Dangerous Trees
8-2-5: Trees And Shrubs At Intersections
8-2-6: Violations And Penalties
8-2-1: PERMITTED TREES:
The Park and Recreation Board shall determine which species of tree are
permitted to be planted as a street tree and may also designate certain species
as not permitted. The Park and Recreation Board may also determine the variety
of such trees to be so planted and the spacing thereof. No person or entity
shall plant a street tree until the proposed street tree's location and species
has been approved by the Park and Recreation Director in writing. (Ord. O2019-
01, 2-4-2019)
8-2-2: INJURY OR DAMAGE PROHIBITED:
   A.   Injury Prohibited: No person shall, in any manner, remove, destroy,
mutilate, cut, deface or otherwise injure or interfere with any trees, shrubs
or plants upon any street, parking or other public ground in the City without a
written permit from the Superintendent of Parks, except that the owner of any
lot or parcel of land may properly trim or remove broken or dead limbs or
branches from trees standing on the parking adjoining such lot or land. (1984
Code § 37-1)
   B.   Placing Material Against Trees: No material of any description shall be
placed against any tree unless the tree is first sufficiently protected by a
proper guard to prevent injury. (1984 Code § 37-7)
   C.   Moving Buildings:
      1.   Injury To Trees By Moving Buildings: No person shall move any
building along any street in such way as to interfere with or injure any tree
in such street without having secured from the building official a permit with
the approval of the Director of Park and Recreation. (1984 Code § 37-8)
      2.   Trimming To Move Buildings: Any trimming or moving of trees made
necessary for the moving of a building or other structure shall be done under
the supervision of the Director of Park and Recreation and at the expense of
the applicant. Should injury or death result to any tree because of such
trimming or moving, the applicant shall, upon direction of the Director of Park
and Recreation, replace the same at his own expense. (1984 Code § 37-4)
   D.   Paving Around Trees: No paving of any description shall be laid or
maintained by anyone between sidewalk and curb which will cut off the air and
water from any street tree. A space of approximately twenty five (25) square
feet shall be left open for each tree, which space may be covered with a
suitable grating, the plans and specifications of which have first been
submitted to and approved by the Director of Park and Recreation. (1984 Code §
37-9; amd. 2005 Code)
   E.   Utility Wires And Cables: The Park and Recreation Board shall have the
power to remove any wire, cable, conduit or other thing that burns, cuts or
chafes any part of any street tree in case the owner of the wires shall fail,
after three (3) days' notice, to take adequate steps to prevent further injury.
(1984 Code § 37-10)
8-2-3: TRIMMING:
   A.   The occupant or owner of any premises abutting upon any street shall
keep all trees standing upon such premises or between the same and the center
of the adjoining streets so trimmed that they comply with the specifications of
the Park and Recreation Board. (1984 Code § 37-2)
   B.   All large established trees shall be trimmed to a sufficient height to
allow free passage of pedestrians and vehicular traffic and in such manner so
as to allow:
      1.   Eight feet (8') clearance over all sidewalks;
      2.   Twelve feet (12') clearance over all local streets and alleys; and
      3.   Fifteen feet (15') clearance over all arterial and collector
streets. (Ord. O2019-01, 2-4-2019)
8-2-4: REMOVAL OF DANGEROUS TREES:
   A.   The owner of any property upon which there is any tree constituting a
hazard to persons or property shall remove the same at his own expense. In case
such owner shall neglect or refuse to remove such a tree upon notice by the
Park and Recreation Board, the same may be removed by the board, and the cost
thereof shall be collected from such owner.
   B.   In the case of a tree constituting a hazard to persons or property
which is located between a property owner's property and the centerline of the
adjoining street, the City shall notify the property owner that the hazardous
tree requires removal. Upon receiving notice, a property owner may choose to
have the tree removed at the property owner's sole expense. In the event such
hazardous tree is not removed within the time designated in the notice, the
Park and Recreation Department may proceed with the removal of said hazardous
tree. The property owner shall be responsible for the costs of such removal
according to rates established by the Park and Recreation Board.
   C.   For the purposes of this section, a tree constituting a hazard is one
that is dead, dying, infected, damaged, or is otherwise in a condition which
poses an unreasonable risk to the health and safety of persons or property.
(Ord. O2019-01, 2-4-2019)
8-2-5: TREES AND SHRUBS AT INTERSECTIONS:
No person shall plant, maintain or permit to grow any tree, hedge, bush or
shrubbery of any kind which has a mature growing height of greater than twenty
four inches (24") within the triangle formed by the adjacent side lines of two
(2) intersecting streets and the line joining points distant thirty five feet
(35') on each side line from their point of intersection. Any tree, hedge, bush
or shrubbery planted or growing within the above defined triangle exceeding
twenty four inches (24") in height is declared a public nuisance and hazard to
public safety and shall be subject to summary abatement by the City by removal.
For the purpose of this section, "side line of street" shall mean the curb line
on those streets where curb is installed, and where curb is not installed,
"side line of street" shall mean that line which otherwise would be the curb
line of a standard City street if such curb was installed and centered within
the right-of-way. (Ord. 1652, 12-18-1989)
8-2-6: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to
a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). The Director of Park and
Recreation shall be responsible for the enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter, and may bring complaints against any individual who shall violate any
provision hereof. (1984 Code § 37-18)
CHAPTER 3
PARKS AND PARKWAYS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Definitions
8-3-2: Public Parks Established
8-3-3: Parkways Established
8-3-4: Rules And Regulations
8-3-5: Prohibited And Restricted Acts And Conditions
8-3-6: Areas Dedicated For Public Use
 
8-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
BOULEVARD: Those strips of land next to public roadways lying between the curb
and the platted line of the adjoining real property used for the planting and
growth of trees and grass. Synonymous with "parking" as defined herein.
PARK: All those tracts of land used or in possession of the city, set apart or
dedicated as places of public recreation.
PARKING: Those strips of land next to public roadways lying between the curb
and the platted line of the adjoining real property used for the planting and
growth of trees and grass. Synonymous with "boulevard" as defined herein.
PARKWAY: Those tracts of land situated on public roadways, not open to public
travel but set apart for the planting and growth of grass, flowers, shrubbery
and trees and the beautifying of the roadway, but not including parkings or
boulevards. (Ord. 2541, 5-16-2016)

as public parks at respective places according to the plats of certain

northeast quarter of section 9, township 103 north, range 60, west of the 5th

Lakeview Municipal Golf Course: The northeast quarter of the southwest quarter

8-3-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Athletic Events:
      1.   Restricted To Designated Areas: No person shall play at any game of
baseball, tennis, football, croquet or other game likely to cause damage to
lawn or surroundings in any park unless such game is played on portions of such
park especially provided and designated for such purpose. (1984 Code § 26-13)
      2.   Scheduling Of Athletic Events: No softball, baseball or other
athletic tournament shall be held upon park property unless the same shall
first be scheduled through the Park and Recreation Office. No such tournament
shall be conducted in such manner as to constitute a violation of any provision
of this Code or other City or State law. (1984 Code § 26-4)
   B.   Concessions:
      1.   Liquor: A permit or license is required by the Governing Body of the
City for any organization or association to sell any alcoholic beverage in any
park.
      2.   Concessions: No person shall sell or offer for sale any article or
operate any concession without first securing a written permit from the Park
and Recreation Board, which shall have the power to fix and collect fees for
such permits. (1984 Code §§ 26-5, 26-23)
   C.   Traffic Regulations:
      1.   Traffic Laws Apply: All provisions of this Code or other ordinances
governing travel or traffic upon public streets shall be applicable within all
parks. (1984 Code § 26-6)
      2.   Vehicles And Horses To Remain On Roadways: No person may operate any
motor vehicle or ride any horse in any park or upon any City property, except
upon drives and roadways specified for such purposes. A bicycle as defined in
section
7-8-1 of this Code is not considered a motor vehicle for the purposes of this
subsection. (Ord. O2019-03, 4-15-2019, eff. 7-1-2019)
      3.   Certain Vehicles Restricted: The Park and Recreation Board shall
have power, whenever it may deem it necessary for safety of the public, to
exclude certain classes of vehicles from any park or from any portion thereof
or to provide that traffic shall move only in one direction. In such cases, the
board shall cause notices to be posted in conspicuous places in such park or
roadways thereof, which notices shall specify such regulation of the board
concerning such traffic. (1984 Code § 26-6)
   D.   Closing Hours: No person shall be or remain in nor leave any vehicle in
any park or parkway, including the public beach, between the hours of eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. and daylight the following morning.
   E.   Additional Rules And Regulations: The Park and Recreation Board may
further regulate the use of the public parks and parkways and the public
beaches; and such other regulations, when posted in a conspicuous place upon
the property, shall be deemed enforceable pursuant to this chapter. Any
violation thereof shall constitute violation pursuant to this chapter. (Ord.
1703, 9-16-1991)
8-3-5: PROHIBITED AND RESTRICTED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Depositing Litter In Parks: No person shall deposit or leave any
litter, bottles, rubbish or garbage in any park, except in containers provided
for such purposes. (1984 Code § 26-7)
   B.   Glass Beverage Containers: No person shall have under his possession or
control any glass beverage container or bottle in any public park or park areas
in the City. The Park and Recreation Department shall cause each of said areas
to be posted with signs in such places and in a manner to give reasonable
notice to the public of the provisions of this subsection. (1984 Code § 26-8)
   C.   Dogs Leashed: All dogs shall be leashed and attended at all times in
any park area, unless in a designated posted leash free park area as designated
by the Park and Recreation Board of the City of Mitchell 1 . (Ord. 2396, 3-19-
2012)
   D.   Injuring Trees Or Plants: No person may pluck, destroy, cut, deface,
break, trample upon, remove, or interfere with the growth of any tree, shrub,
or flower in any park or parkway, unless the Parks and Recreation Director has
approved such action in writing prior to its occurrence. (Ord. O2019-04, 4-15-
2019)
   E.   Injuring Property: No person shall deface, mar, injure, break or tamper
with any water connection, hydrant, building or other improvement in any park
or parkway 2 . (1984 Code § 26-11)
   F.   Posting Bills Prohibited 3 : (Rep. by Ord. 2422, 1-21-2013)
   G.   Camping In Parks: No person shall park or camp any motor vehicle driven
camper or recreational vehicle or pull type camper or travel trailer overnight
on any City park or City owned property at Lake Mitchell, including the
designated beaches, boat ramps, parks and public access areas, without prior
written permission from the Director of Park and Recreation. (Ord. 1600, 7-5-
1988)

CHAPTER 4
LAKE MITCHELL
SECTION:
8-4-1: Swimming And Floating Regulations
8-4-2: Boating Regulations
8-4-3: Approach Intake Tower
8-4-1: SWIMMING AND FLOATING REGULATIONS:
   A.   Any and all persons swimming, wading or floating on any type of raft,
air mattress, innertube or floatation device, whatsoever, must stay within one
hundred feet (100') of the shoreline. This section shall not apply to any
person water skiing upon the lake.
   B.   No person shall swim, wade or in any way float on any floatation
device, innertube, air mattress or raft of any type in the bay area lying
within the east boat ramp area, as the same is defined in section
8-3-2 of this title (commonly known as the old boat ramp area), or within fifty
feet (50') of either side of the west boat ramp, as defined in section
8-3-2 of this title (commonly known as the new boat ramp area), upon Lake
Mitchell. (1984 Code § 18A-3)
8-4-2: BOATING REGULATIONS:
   A.   Speed Limits:
      1.   No boat of whatever size operated upon Lake Mitchell shall exceed a
speed at any time or any place of more than forty (40) miles per hour unless
special permission has been granted by the city council for organized and
approved boating exhibitions or events.
      2.   All boats operated upon Lake Mitchell must reduce their speed to not
in excess of five (5) miles per hour when operating within one hundred feet
(100') of the shoreline or within fifty feet (50') of any other boat.
      3.   No person shall operate any boat or vehicle of any nature upon the
Lake Mitchell at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the
conditions then existing, nor shall he operate at a speed greater than the
posted limits upon any area within Lake Mitchell. (1984 Code § 18A-1)
   B.   Exhibition Boating Prohibited: No person shall drive or operate any
boat or other vehicle of whatever nature upon Lake Mitchell in such a manner
that it creates or causes unnecessary engine noise, swing or sway upon
acceleration or stopping or that simulates a temporary race or that causes the
boat or vehicle to unnecessarily turn abruptly or sway. (1984 Code § 18A-2)
   C.   No Wake During High Water: During any time at which the water level in
Lake Mitchell reaches the height of twelve inches (12") or more over the level
of the top of the spillway, no person shall operate any boat or watercraft upon
the surface of Lake Mitchell at such speed or in such manner as shall cause or
create a wake. This regulation, once in effect because of the high water level,
shall remain in effect until such time as the water level of the lake drops to
the level of six inches (6") over the level of the top of the spillway. (Ord.
1749, 9-20-1993)
8-4-3: APPROACH INTAKE TOWER:
No person, other than officers or employees of the city acting in pursuit of
duty, shall approach nearer than one hundred feet (100') from the intake tower
of the water system of the city, now located in Lake Mitchell, for any purpose
or by any means whatsoever. (1984 Code § 18A-4)

PUBLIC LIBRARY
SECTION:

8-5-2: Library Board Of Trustees

as provided by statute 1 . Their duties shall be as provided by statute. (1984
Code § 19-2)

CHAPTER 6
CEMETERIES
SECTION:
8-6-1: Cemeteries Established
8-6-2: Graceland Cemetery
8-6-1: CEMETERIES ESTABLISHED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain, create or operate
any cemetery within the city or within one mile thereof or upon any public
grounds, airport or park belonging to the city or within one mile of such
public ground, airport or park without first having procured the approval and
consent of the city council. Notice of the hearing for approval and consent
shall be given by the city council by publication one week prior thereto in the
official newspaper for the city. No such consent and approval or application
therefor shall be required for any cemetery which has been in continuous
operation as a cemetery for five (5) or more consecutive years. (1984 Code § 8-
1)
8-6-2: GRACELAND CEMETERY:
   A.   Cemetery Established 1 : Graceland cemetery, heretofore established by
the city in the southeast quarter of section 9, township 103 and range 60 in
Davison County, South Dakota, as shown by the records in the office of the
register of deeds of the county, shall continue to be maintained and regulated
as provided in this section. (1984 Code § 8-2; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Records: The finance officer shall keep, in his office, an interment
record showing all facts shown by the monthly report of the public works
department and shall also keep a deed record showing the sale and ownership of
all burial lots and such other records and books of account as may be required
by resolution of the city council. (1984 Code § 8-5)
   C.   Public Burial Ground: The north half of block 1 of the cemetery and
such other spaces within said cemetery as shall be designated by the city
council shall continue to be used for the burial of those persons for the
burial of whom no other place has been provided and shall be and remain a
public burying ground. The graves therein shall be dug and numbered by the
public works department in consecutive order, beginning at the north line of
the north lot of the burying ground, thence running south, and the public works
department shall erect and maintain at each of such graves a marker whereon
shall be cut the number thereof and the name of the person buried therein.
Whenever any burial has been made on any lot in the ground, no burial shall be
made on any other lot thereof until such first lot is full. (1984 Code § 8-6)
   D.   Plats And Sales Of Lots:
      1.   Established Plats: The plats of Graceland cemetery appearing of
record in the office of the register of deeds of the county are hereby
recognized as the established plats of the cemetery.
      2.   Sale Of Lots: The price at which lots in the cemetery shall be sold
and conditions on which lots in the cemetery shall be sold and conditions on
which such sales may be made shall continue to be fixed by the city council.
(1984 Code § 8-7)
   E.   Graves And Mausoleums:
      1.   All graves shall be at least six feet (6') deep, except that
mausoleums may be constructed aboveground in an area designated by the city
council by resolution, and provided that said mausoleums meet the following
minimum specifications:
         a.   Walls: Walls shall be a minimum of four inches (4") thick with
the outside walls to be granite only and inside walls to be either granite or
concrete.
         b.   Roofs: Roofs shall be granite only and, if not one piece, shall
have a lap between sections of at least six inches (6").
         c.   Foundation: Foundations shall be approved by the building
official of the city.
         d.   Windows And Doors: Any glass or stained glass windows shall be
protected by tempered glass at least one inch (1") thick and shall be fitted in
a bronze frame, which is solidly anchored into the granite wall. All doors
shall be heavy bronze, and any door or windows shall be of lexan glass or
similar material only and not of plate glass. (1984 Code § 8-8)
      2.   Surface Of Graves: The surface of all graves shall be maintained on
a level with the surrounding area sufficient to permit mowing over graves.
(1984 Code § 8-9)
   F.   Monuments:
      1.   Construction Of Monument Foundations: The foundations of all
monuments erected in the cemetery shall extend below the frost line and be
solidly constructed of stone or cement. (1984 Code § 8-10)
      2.   Number Of Monuments And Markers Per Lot: No more than one central
monument shall be erected on any lot, and no more than one marker shall be
placed on each grave. (1984 Code § 8-11)
   G.   Public Access To Cemetery; Hours: The cemetery and all its grounds
shall be closed to all vehicular and/or pedestrian traffic each day from ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. the following morning. Easter
Sunday and the following Monday morning and Christmas Eve and Christmas morning
shall be excepted from the foregoing access restriction. Any person found
within the boundaries of the cemetery grounds or upon any roadway within the
cemetery, except persons specifically authorized by the director of public
works, shall be deemed in violation of this subsection and, upon arrest and
conviction thereof, shall be subject to fine as provided in the general penalty
in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 1635, 5-15-1989; amd. 2005 Code)
   H.   Prohibited And Restricted Acts And Conditions:
      1.   Fences; Planting Trees And Shrubs: No fence or coping shall be
erected on or around any lot in the cemetery nor shall any tree or shrub be
planted therein without the consent of the city council. (1984 Code § 8-12)
      2.   Children Under Fourteen: No child under fourteen (14) years of age
shall be allowed to enter the cemetery unless accompanied by some person of
discretion having such child then in charge, and such person shall be
responsible for the conduct and acts of such child while therein. (1984 Code §
8-13)
      3.   Injuring Property; Placing Signs: No person shall break, pluck or
otherwise injure any wild or cultivated plant or break or otherwise injure any
tree or shrub or deface or mar any monument or make any mark thereon by writing
or otherwise or injure any landmark or otherwise injure the cemetery or any
part thereof or deface or injure any part of the fence around or upon the
cemetery or paint or otherwise put up any sign upon any part of any fence
around or upon the cemetery. (1984 Code § 8-14)
      4.   Dogs At Large: No person having custody of any dog shall permit such
animal to run at large in the cemetery 1 . (1984 Code § 8-15) (amd. Ord. O2022-
09, 6-21-2022)
 
Notes
1 1. SDCL § 9-32-13 et seq.
1 1. See section
  6-1-3 of this code.
CHAPTER 7
CORN PALACE AUDITORIUM
SECTION:
8-7-1: Management And Control
8-7-2: Operating Fund
8-7-1: MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL 1 :
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter and title 3, chapter 9 of this
code, the control, management and operation of the Corn Palace auditorium shall
remain directly with the city council. (1984 Code § 9-1)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 4-2-7 of this code for Corn Palace liquor licenses.
8-7-2: OPERATING FUND:
   A.   Fund Established: That certain fund, heretofore authorized by
resolution, is continued and shall be known as the Corn Palace operating fund.
Such fund shall be used exclusively by the Corn Palace entertainment board 1
as working capital and to absorb any deficit which may result from the
operations as herein authorized. (1984 Code § 9-6; amd. Ord. 2487, 10-20-2014)
   B.   Fiscal Year: The fiscal year of the board shall end on November 30 of
each year, at which time, the board shall transfer to the Corn Palace operating
fund from the net income then on hand, such amount as may be necessary, if
available, to replace any deficit which may have resulted from operations
during such fiscal year and to maintain the fund in such amount as the city
council may, by resolution, be determined.
   C.   Annual Report: On January 1 of each year, the board shall file with the
finance officer an itemized annual report covering the last fiscal year and
showing all receipts and all disbursements, including any amount transferred to
the Corn Palace operating fund as above provided, and showing the balance on
hand at the close of the year, which balance shall be paid to the finance
officer who shall first place such amount thereof as may be fixed by resolution
of the city council, or so much thereof as may be available, in the general
fund as an offset against current expenses of operating and maintaining the
auditorium, and any balance shall be placed by the finance officer in a special
fund to be known as the Corn Palace reserve fund. Such annual report shall be
presented to the city council at the first regular meeting in January of each
year.
   D.   Disbursement Of Revenue:
      1.   All revenues derived through Corn Palace activities shall be
receipted into the appropriate fund by the finance officer and all
disbursements shall be by warrant authorized by the Corn Palace committee.
      2.   No debt shall be incurred by the board without the approval of a
majority of the board members of a regular or special meeting, and all
disbursements shall be made by check to be signed by the secretary and
treasurer of the board. (1984 Code § 9-6)
 
Notes
1 2. See title 3, chapter 9 of this code.
CHAPTER 8
WATER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:
8-8-1: Authority To Regulate
8-8-2: Water Division
8-8-3: Application Of Provisions
8-8-4: Connection To City Water System
8-8-5: Construction Regulations
8-8-6: Curb Stops And Service Boxes
8-8-7: Water Meters
8-8-8: Application For Water Service
8-8-9: Rates And Charges
8-8-10: Water Conservation Measures
8-8-11: Maintenance Of System
8-8-12: Cross Connections
8-8-13: Prohibited Acts
8-8-14: Enforcement
8-8-15: Violations And Penalties
8-8-1: AUTHORITY TO REGULATE 1 :
   A.   The city council shall have authority to regulate the distribution and
use of water supplied by the city and shall have the authority to permit a
reasonable use of water in any case necessary to maintain adequate health and
sanitation standards. (1984 Code §§ 38-35, 38-37)
   B.   The city council may, by resolution, prohibit the sale of water to any
persons or parties, which water is not for use within the city. (1984 Code §
38-39)
   C.   All fees and charges for use and connection to the water system of the
city shall be as established from time to time by resolution of the city
council. (2005 Code)
   D.   Any resolution passed pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed to be an
emergency resolution. (1984 Code § 38-40)
 
Notes
1 1. SDCL §§ 9-32-8, 9-47-1.
8-8-2: WATER DIVISION:
   A.   Division Of Department Of Public Works: The water division is a
division of the public works department and shall be administered by said
department. There shall be a superintendent of water within this division.
(1984 Code § 38-1; amd. 2005 Code)
   B.   Authority Of Officers And Employees: The officers and employees of the
water division of the public works department shall have power to enter the
premises or buildings of consumers at any reasonable hour for the purpose of
reading, removing, installing, testing or repairing meters or for examining
piping. Such official or employee shall have power to shut the water off from
any premises for nonpayment of water bills, to enforce repair of service
between water main and meter, to prevent waste of water or to shut the water
off from any main for the purpose of repairs or improvements. If necessary to
dig up or repair to corporation cock or curb cock to shut off water, the cost
of such labor and materials required may be added to the water bill for such
premises and considered part of the same. (1984 Code § 38-4)
   C.   Records Kept: Proper cost accounting and operation records shall be
maintained by the director of public works in such manner as to be readily
accessible to the city council. Records of plant operation shall show all
pertinent data relating to pumpage and chemical treatment from day to day and
shall also be consolidated into figures of operation by calendar month. Proper
records of all water meters shall be maintained showing tests and repairs made,
date of purchase, where installed and similar pertinent data. (1984 Code § 38-
6)
   D.   Annual Reports: As soon as practicable after the end of a calendar
year, an annual report shall be prepared by the director of public works and
filed with finance officer. Such report shall cover both operational data and
financial data pertinent to the previous calendar year's operation of the water
division. The report shall be accompanied by a detailed inventory of all water
department property (1984 Code § 38-7)
   E.   Water Enterprise Fund: A fund to be known as the water enterprise fund
shall be established for accounting purposes within the general fund of the
city. All money and credits collected under this chapter, including fines and
fees for violations of the same, shall be credited to the water enterprise
fund. (Ord. 1496, 3-5-1984)
8-8-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all persons using water
regardless of whether any person shall have a contract for water service with
the city. (1984 Code § 38-41)
8-8-4: CONNECTION TO CITY WATER SYSTEM:
   A.   Permit To Tap Water Mains:
      1.   Permit Required: No person shall tap any water main without first
securing a permit therefor, the cost of which shall be as established by the
director of public works with the approval of the city council.
      2.   Issuance Of Permit: Upon exhibition of the finance officer's receipt
for the proper fee, the director of public works shall issue the permit to tap
the water main, which tap shall be made only by competent public works
employees. The service shall be installed by and under the direction of a
licensed master plumber. Tapping permits shall be signed by the owner or his
agent and shall carry the name of the licensed plumber authorized to make the
installation of the service.
   B.   Cost Of Connection Supplies: The cost of pipe, curbs top, stop box and
all other water service appurtenances, including the cost of cutting and
repavement, shall be paid by the owner and shall not be included in the fee
paid for tap permit. The city shall furnish and install the necessary
corporation cock with the cost thereof to be charged to the owner as part of
the tapping fee. (1984 Code § 38-9)
   C.   Authorized Person To Perform Work; Restrictions:
      1.   Persons Authorized: No person, except a licensed plumber or public
works employee, shall connect with the city water mains or shall perform any
work upon any pipes or fixtures connected with such service. Such plumber shall
comply with all ordinances, rules or regulations that now or may hereafter be
adopted by the city. (1984 Code § 38-15)
      2.   Plumber's Restrictions:
         a.   No plumber shall commence work of any kind mentioned in
subsection C1 hereof until a permit for such service has been secured. (1984
Code §38-16; amd. 2005 Code)
         b.   Upon completion of the test of a new service, the plumber shall
turn the water off at the curb stop and shall not again turn it on.
         c.   In case of leaks or other accidents to pipes or apparatus
connected with the city water mains, the plumber may shut off the water to make
the necessary repairs.
         d.   In all cases, a plumber shall have the water shut off or turned
on as he found it to be when he commenced work on the service or premises,
except that the corporation cock on approved new or repaired services shall be
left open.
         e.   No plumber or other person shall extend water pipes from one
premises to another without permission from the director of public works. (1984
Code § 38-16)
   D.   Required Connections:
      1.   Connections Required: Whenever the city council shall deem it
necessary to construct water service connections from the water main to behind
the curb line in any streets or alleys, a resolution shall be passed by the
city council requiring the property owners, whose property has not been
connected with the water main, to construct such connecting service lines from
the water main to behind the curb line in the streets or alleys, within the
time specified, not less than thirty (30) days from the passage of the
resolution.
      2.   Notice To Owners: The resolution shall contain a notice to the
owners stating that work is to be done and the time within which they are
required to do it. Such notice may be general as to owners, but must be
specific as to the description of the lots or parcels of ground in front of
which such property connections are to be constructed. (1984 Code § 38-26)
      3.   City's Right To Have Work Done At Owner's Cost:
         a.   If such water connections are not built, laid and constructed in
the manner and within the time prescribed in said resolution, the city council
may order the same to be done by such person as it may contract with and under
the direction of the director of public works, at the expense of the lots and
parcels of land adjoining in front of and for the benefit of which said water
connections have been laid, built and constructed. Such expense shall be
assessed on said lots and parcels of land, so changeable, by the director of
public works and approved by the city council, and in accordance with South
Dakota Codified Laws chapter 9-47-1 and all amendments thereto.
         b.   Payment shall be due and payable after the filing of the
assessment roll with the finance officer and shall be collected in the same
manner as other special assessments are now collected as provided by law.
         c.   All steps taken for the charge of the property affected in the
collecting of such assessment and the selling of such property in default of
payment of such assessments shall be done and performed in the same manner as
all other special assessments for local improvements as are now collected by
the city. (1984 Code § 38-27)
   E.   Disconnection Of Abandoned Services: Upon abandoning any water service,
the water line shall be disconnected at the main. The property owner shall be
required to engage a licensed plumber to perform the work in a manner
satisfactory to the director of public works. (1984 Code § 38-29)
8-8-5: CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Service Pipe And Distribution System Installation: A service pipe shall
be considered the water line extending from a water main to a meter. Fire lines
not connected to a meter shall be considered a service pipe extending from the
water main to a building wall. (Ord. 1610, 11-7-1988)
All underground water distribution systems shall be constructed in accordance
with state statute and the uniform plumbing code. (1984 Code § 38-30; amd. 2005
Code)
      1.   Pipe Size: The minimum size water service line shall be one inch
(1"). However, in repair work if only a portion of the existing service needs
replacing, the existing size may be continued. (Ord. 1610, 11-7-1988)
      2.   Coverage Of Pipes: Minimal cover for underground piping shall be six
feet (6'). (1984 Code § 38-30)
      3.   Types Of Pipe: Only copper pipe shall be used for any size service
line through two inch (2") pipe within the street right of way. If any existing
noncopper service line is repaired or replaced within the street right or way,
that portion replaced within the street right of way, that portion between the
water main and the curb stop or six feet (6') from the property line, whichever
is farthest, shall be repaired or replaced with copper pipe. For sizes over two
inches (2") only copper, ductile iron or polyvinylchloride pipe shall be used.
         a.   Copper pipe shall be type K or type L meeting the requirements of
ASTM B88. Copper water service pipe shall be installed with flared type joints.
         b.   Ductile iron pipe shall comply with the requirements of the AWWA
C151. For sizes through four inch (4"), the pipe shall be class 51. For sizes
over four inch (4"), the pipe shall be class 50. That portion of a ductile iron
pipe service line within a street right of way shall be wrapped with minimum
eight mill polyethylene sheeting meeting the requirements of AWWA C105.
         c.   Polyvinylchloride (PVC) pipe shall conform to the AWWA standard
C900 and shall be class 150, SDR-18, minimum, with integral bell and spigot
joints.
      4.   Pipe Installation Requirements:
